reviewText:
9.5/10

genre : 3rd person action with horror elements

The game takes place 3 years after the events of the first game and you play as Isaac Clarke fighting from the very first moment of the game for your life in a space station known as the Sprawl, haunted by things no man should ever have seen and by the  fact that your girlfriend died on Ishimura.

+ Great presentation and graphical detail, great use of light that amplfies the atmosphere, Isaac looks great. Game runs with no problems maxed out.
+ Voice acting is fine, sound effects are also great, you will often wonder if that sound is a monster creeping up on you or just a piece of metal rolling around.
+ Gameplay wise the combat is more satisfying than in the original and melee is also done better.  There are some new weapon additions , but the plasma cutter and pulse rifle are still your best bet just as they were in the first game.
+ Nice idea with the space suit, that implements interesting gameplay elements.
+ Some clever puzzles, although not that challenging.
+ Hard Core mode is unlocked after you finish the game at least once and in addition to tougher enemies and fewer supplies, you can save your progress only 3 times.

- Game is faster paced than the original, maybe faster than what a horror game should be.
- After a while enemies become predictable, both the way they appear and the way they fight.
- Multiplayer is nothing special.

A classic action/horror game , a beautiful single player experience, even though it's a linear and after a while a predictable one, a game i recommend to everyone who is looking for a solid single player and intense experience.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is amazing. It takes everything the original put into the series, and enhances it. The controls are more precise, smooth and convenient (with the addition of a single button health and stasis refill system), the visuals are even more detailed and gritty, the sound is as creepy as ever, and the story remains intriguing and intense. You must work to unravel the truth behind the Sprawl (the game's setting), Unitology and Necromorphs, as well as battling (literally) horrific hallucinations and delusions from an alien form of dementia. If you are a fan of the first, then you will definitely enjoy this.

While the base game mechanics are not terribly different from many over-the-shoulder style third person shooters, several aspects are worth mentioning. One of the hallmarks of Dead Space 2 is that it forces players to use weapons to defeat enemies in a different way. In a time when headshots are the gold standard for 99% of games, Dead Space 2 requires players to sever limbs in order to defeat enemies--well-placed head shots will get you nowhere. This is a refreshing change of pace, as the dismemberment strategy will change based on enemy type (there are several), and thus every battle becomes much more tactical. There are also a wide variety of unique weapons to choose from, and each weapon will serve a different purpose in your arsenal, depending on how you want to fine tune your Necromorph killing strategy. Puzzles are frequent enough to serve as welcome breaks from the tense action, but not too frequent to become annoying.

Atmosphere was my main draw to DS1 and now DS2. Visceral Games has managed to create this incredibly immersive environment that manages to literally keep me trying to be prepared for what they may throw at me next. In my opinion, the number one contributor to creating such an unrivaled level of atmosphere is the sound design. Anyone who plays this game owes it to themselves to have it on a good home theater system or at least some good quality headphones. The surround sound not only adds to the spookiness of the game, but delivers vital information of approaching creatures. Even in areas with no baddies to kill, the sounds of metallic creaks, cracks and scrapes in the Sprawl's ventilation system let you know you're never safe. Indeed DS2 has some cheap scares, but they're so well timed and not always predictable that I have a hard time believing someone who says they never jumped during a play through.

The music is well composed, and only adds to the atmosphere. The music is also well timed and sometimes gives you the impression that something large is coming. Sometimes it never happens, while other times it does. It manages to build levels of tension and keep you on your toes, never taking for granted the next dark hallway, for a necro is commonly waiting in unseen corners.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed Dead Space 2. One does not have to be familiar with the first to enjoy this, as there is a Previous on Dead Space" menu option available to bring newcomers up to par; however
date: to get the most from the story

reviewText:
It has you checking every corpse in sight with a ranged gunshot to make sure that they're not going to reanimate and slice your body apart.

The horror within this game cannot be described with mere words, videos and images are enough to keep you on edge, but being inside the game immerses you to the point where you almost emulate the fear that the player is enduring, a truly shocking experience.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=394410201
You play as Isaac Clarke in the aftermath of Dead Space 1's events, you are lead to believe that you have a mental issue which can be cured if you listen to who is talking to you, both Isaac's ambition to survive the odds given rise to by these messages and your own ambition to run through the blood still keeps you going through the game, despite the offputting level of horror and terror.

Excruciatingly terrifying at a certain point where Isaac re-enters the USG Ishimura, only to be met by a swarm of unstoppable necromorphs which swarm him like wasps, the paranoia you feel when you hear a distant necromorph, thinking you've killed them all, and you think they're too far away to reach you in time, but just as you go to run, it's fangs are buried in your leg is undescribable.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=394410249
Most definately a game that gets you thinking; you constantly run in to obstacles which enable you to use your mind to utilize many game mechanics such as Telekinesis and freezing, you are able to freeze certain obstacles in time to ensure that they don't slice you in to millions of pieces as you crawl towards your objective.

Do I reccommend this game? absolutely! but it is not for the weak of heart, nor for those who find themselves constantly ragequitting in every game they play.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=394410288
Watch your step, don't turn around unless you hear a ♥♥♥♥ing noise, and most certainly never think that you're alone.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is the follow on from the original Dead Space, a survival horror action game.  The game was released in 2011.  The plot is set three years after the events of Dead Space 1, and we are playing again as Isaac Clarke. This time we get to hear his voice though!

Like the original, you play in a third-person perspective looking just over the right hand shoulder. Pretty much everything gameplay wise is identical to the original too. The only change I did come across is that all of the weapons and suite upgrades are all unlocked from the start which I thought was a little odd, I just stuck with a trusty pulse rifle rather than gungho with a flamethrower... The hacking system is again done very well here, slightly different to #1 but still just as compelling and simple enough to complete.

The graphics are also slightly better here; this game is made using the Visceral Engine (unlike the first), which some may be familiar with if they have played the Battlefield series of games. This game does look phenomenal though; even now at four years old.

Story wise follows on from the first game, I would say you need to play the original if you want to understand what is happening as I think it would leave you with lots of unanswered questions if you don't. I'm not sure what else they can do with the story; however I will surely find out when I play the third in the series soon. That being said; I finished the game in two sittings which for me that is quite an achievement and means the story had me immersed straight away.

As Dead Space 1 had, Dead Space 2 has amazing audio too; jump scares, screams, music changes, all of it adds up to make this a horror experience you won't forget in a long time. If you don't find jump scares frightening, you probably won't find any other aspect of the game scary though.

We have a couple of difficulty settings; I would not recommend Easy mode unless you are purely playing for the story as you will not die when playing. Once you complete the game you also unlock an even harder mode to playthrough.

All of the levels are well designed and include lots of corridors swarming with activity in for you to explore for extra pickups and ammo. Some of the areas are the same ones as in the first, but this is very minimal and only used for story reasons.

A full playthrough of Dead Space 2 took me about thirteen hours, which is a similar time to the first. I am perfectly happy with the amount of content the game has to offer, it is a linear story mode so I wouldn't expect any more time wise. There is a hint of replay-ability with new game+ modes, but realistically I don't see there being another reason to play it more than once.

No massive technical problems while playing; the only issue I had was the game plays at 30 fps. However this can be changed using nVidia or AMD card options,a link to this how to guide here:

http://solidlystated.com/software/dead-space-2-30-fps-limit-bypass/

I would also note that the Steam store for this game says it uses a 3rd party DRM called Tages, however I do not think it is used anymore, I have no software installed, nor do I get any prompts for it in game. I think it is safe to ignore that warning now.

In conclusion, Dead Space 2 is an absolutely stunning sequel in the Dead Space series; I loved this game just as much as the first. I really recommend people give this game ago if they haven't already.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/47780

reviewText:
Pros
-The story is pretty fun, the new characters are well realised.
-The gameplay is vastly improved compared to the first one
-The sound design is still top notch.
-Isaac speaks now and has more of a personality
-Some setpieces can bring up a lot of tension
-The first 10 chapters are good...


Cons
-...The last five turn the game into a straight up shooter.
-Only a few new enemies compared to Dead Space.
-Relies a lot more on jump scares than the first one
-Isaac speaks now and has more of a personality.

Neutral
-Too many enemies thrown at you toward the end of the game (especially the last 2 chapters)
-No character as creepy as Dr. Mercer.



The game feel at the same time familiar and different. The enemies are mostly the same, the dismemberment is still here and still feels good, the gameplay has been refined and the production value has increased resulting in a better game but not necessarily a better Dead Space game. If you are looking for more Dead Space, you will be able to find it here but be ready for a lot more action than the first game.

reviewText:
After playing this game a few times through, I found that it is one of the most realistic and most terrifying horror experiences ever created, I'm here to review it.

Overview:
Dead Space™ 2 is an extremely realistic horror experience that is, in my opinion, the best in the series. This is because of its outstandingly realistic visuals, sounds and jump-scares that will keep you on the edge of your seat all of the way through your experience. It has an amazing storyline (that you really need to play the first game to understand) and I would recommend it to anyone who is a fan of horror, and I'm here to tell you why.

Presentation:
Dead Space™ 2 has some of the most outstanding visuals in any horror game I've ever seen. Horror games aren't even meant to look realistic! They usually just scare you with jump-scares and extremely scary sounds. This game does a lot more than that, and that's why it's my favourite in the series. It has amazing detail, from hovering around space to stomping on necromorph corpses, or even seeing a man getting possessed from behind by some huge-claw wielding monster. Even changing into a different suit looks amazing! If you're one of those people who is usually fussy with bad graphics and you want something more realistic-looking, this is definitely one of the games for you. But these graphics aren't the only amazing thing about this game, there is much, much more that makes this my favourite horror game to date.

Gameplay:
Now here is where Dead Space™ 2 never fails to impress, the gameplay. From quick-time events that require you to press/mash a certain key to save your skin - to shooting off a necromorph's legs with a Plasma Cutter. This games' gameplay aspect definitely didn't fail to impress me. Well, running around in a straight-jacket away from man-eating monsters is always fun, especially when you jump right into it. This game jumps right into action, this is what I really love! When you really don't expect it, you could be mauled by a huge boss from nowhere, or even just a gunship commanded by people who want you dead. This game also has a great inventory system, (requiring you to be away from necromorphs to actually open it safely) which helps you keep track of your weapons, ammo and highly-profitable conductors. These can all be sold at stores for credits, which can be used to buy other weapons, suits and nodes. (to upgrade your RIG) Your RIG helps you to stay alive, you can upgrade it using power nodes. This is one thing that is more in-depth than it was in the original Dead Space™, (along with a much wider variety of suits/armour) you can upgrade weapons and your RIG with these power nodes that you can either buy or scavenge from around the Dead Space™ world. The best part of this game in my opinion is stomping on necromorphs after they're down to collect their loot, now who wouldn't say that's fun? I'm guessing people who aren't utterly crazy, and if you've already played this game; you must be!

Verdict/Summary:
Dead Space™ 2 is the most realistic and terrifying experiences to date, (in my opinion of course) I'm sure a lot of the people who have already played and completed this game many times would agree with that statement. This game proves that you don't need an open-world to have an amazing game! If you want jump-scares, action and realistic gameplay with an amazing plot/storyline; this is definitely the game for you.

9.5/10: Amazing!

Pros:
Amazingly realistic visuals
Lots of action
Great story
Flawless gameplay

Cons:
Linear Storyline

I recommend this to anyone who enjoys horror!

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is pretty cool, I guess.

Set a few months after the events of Dad Space, a reverse horror game where an irate Space Engineer violently hunts and exterminates Space Zombies aboard a Space Ship orbiting a Space Planet with about as much efficiency and brutality as you would expect from someone who never has a chance to use his degree outside of murder.

You once again play as Isaac Clarke, the galaxy's most notorious mass murderer born from two dads. Isaac is less than sane after the events of the first game and is put into a holding cell aboard a space station city while constrained with a  straitjacket in hopes of containing his endless blood lust.

It didn't.

About two minutes into the game, Isaac is awoken by a crazy man who wishes to release the eternal man slayer from his confines. Unfortunately, Issac's devout follower is attacked by an infector (That's what the wiki calls them, don't hold me to it.) and turns him into a horrible space monster. A space monster that Isaac promptly headbutts in the face and knocks flat on it's ♥♥♥. Honestly, they could have just kept Isaac from being able to use his arms through the entire game just to make it fair.

Now, I played Dad Space and Dads Space back to back over the course of a few days now. And I immediately noticed a difference between the two. For one, I personally preferred using a controller during Dad Space because the aiming felt sluggish with a mouse. This is gone in Dads Space, now that Isaac apparently remembered he's the only competent person in the galaxy and quick shoots like a master. It's almost like he's been shooting at these things for two games now or something.

The second game was developed by Visceral games as opposed to Redwood. They must have taken criticisms from the first game to heart because, not only can Isaac still punch a zombies head clean off it's body, but he's also stronger, faster, and a better shot than he was in the first game. If the Earth government was smart they would stop trying to clone the marker  and instead Clone Isaac Clarke, effectively making an unstoppable super soldier army that also knows how a ship engine works.

But honestly, at this point, I'm 100% sure that either someone at EA or their developer teams have no idea how a horror game should work. The Ishimura wasn't really all that spooky, sure, but it was fun to explore. There was this almost classic Resident Evil vibe to going from room to room and robbing dead people while going through their personal diaries.

But Titan Station is just too linear for it's own good. It feels like you're being led down a long hallway with a few branches now and then rather than exploring a space station. It keeps the plot moving forward, sure, but they could have padded it out better with more audio logs to discover and maybe even some survivors every now and then. In the original Dad Space, Isaac would sometimes run into a survivor on the Ishimura, sure they usually died or were way past the point of return, but it made the Ishimura feel like a place people actually lived and worked on for months at a time.

After a few chapters in the beginning of the game, Titan Station just kind of empties out, something I can't believe considering big the space city is supposed to be. Unless there was free chipotle being handed out earlier and everyone just had to go to the bathroom all at once, I don't get how so many people would have been evacuated or killed so quickly.

Oh, and Isaac talks now. I mean, he had a single line in the first game, but now he can speak full sentences that aren't just grunting and yelling loudly. Also, he no longer runs like a girl, good on you, Isaac.

But should you play Dads Space?

That depends, how much do you like shooting stuff? Dad Space isn't really a frightening series, I mean, it isn't to me. Dads Space itself is a solid game with some questionable design choices. I mean, near the end of the game there's an on rail shooting segment. Come on, guys.

Some disturbing imagery stands out, like the crying baby behind an apartment door which implies the parents either abandoned it or were killed before hand. Or the guy in the beginning of the game that wiped his own dooky on the floor. No, I'm serious, I even took a screenshot, here it is. http://i.imgur.com/2ZrRKga.jpg
That's crazy, is that how you want to be remembered? The guy who died wiping his poo poo on the walls? Who's idea was that? Was it you, Steve Papoutsis: lead producer of Dead space 2? Are you the doo doo guy?

If you like the series, then why are you even reading this? But if you want to get into the series and liked the first one? You'll probably like Dads Space's gameplay more than Dad Spaces but probably not the setting and atmosphere.

Dad's Space gets 5 Engineers cussing while stomping boxes out of 6.

And now I move on to Dad3 Space while we wait for Dad Resurrection Space.

The curator, I assure you I spend a lot less time talking about poop walls here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

reviewText:
Ok so let's start of by saying that last time we saw Isaac Clarke he was shall we say not alltogether sane after his experience with his time spent on the planetcracker USG Ishimura and even though we knew it wasent over we didnt know of the horror that was to come.
Set three years after the event's in the original Dead Space,this time protagonist Isaac Clarke find's hinself in a fight for his life against a new Necromorph outbreak on the Sprawl,a space station above Saturn's largest moon,Titan.
Isaac is at a disadvantage right from the get go as he is believed to have lost his mind and when the outbreak kick's of this time he is in a straitjacket strapped on an upright bed and wondering if this is it?????
Of course he need not worry as a certain Franco Delille set's him free (protagonist of Dead Space Ignition) but we all know what happen's to character's that are'nt that important in these games dont we (NO WHAT HAPPEN'S TO THEM????-ARE YOU HAVING ME ON OR WHAT?????)

Dead Space 2 - Launch Trailer - YouTube

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=776fi2I8e6U

Right as allways down to the brass tac's of the game and first of the most important aspect for this game the story.Now i for one was wondering how they would carry on the story and for the second part of what has so far been a trilogy they have hit the nail on the head.
Is the story in this game told as well as in the first?????,yes and no is the answer and i will explain why on both points.
When i say yes it makes me happy to say that,as this was one game i didnt want them to mess up on and i am happy to say they didnt and the story flow's and take's you on a journey that (if your a fan of the original) you wont forget.Now let me explain why i said no,i really enjoyed the first game and the story but i dont remember Isaac being (for use of a better term) a potty mouth".Now im not a prude (far from it) but i find the change in Isaac not one that i appriciated or liked but i must say i didnt find that it put me of at all (but it was there in the back of my mind whilst playing).
Now to say more about what goes on than i allready have will not only spoil all the surprise's the game has in store for you but also all the terror and sheer shock's you will get from discovering it on your own (and you would'ent want those spolit now would you????).
Now the sound in game (just like in the first game) really does a fantastic job of building tension and really does help to move the game along and without it

reviewText:
Dead Space™ 2 feels and behaves like the first Dead Space™ installment, but adds more monsters and continues with Isaac's story. I must say that I liked this one a little better in some parts, although most of the horror from the first game is gone (some jumpscares here and there but overall the fear element is removed, which is good because nothing can surprise us now after the first time).

The Steam version has all the DLC bundled, and has all the goodies unlocked, so you'll just grab one or two suits along the game and that's it, you won't be too tempted with the schematics. You can disable this though, or just ignore the suits, if you want to have a bigger challenge.

The story is superb and the gameplay is really good. Graphically speaking is the same as many 2010s games, and has a lot of atmosphere, lens flares and all that stuff EA loves.

you get sent to a mental hospital where the necromorphs start atttacking.
there is more to the story but i wont spoil it for u guys.
there is a HIGH amount of gore and I MEAN high.
i think this is the only gory game i have played where headshots are inefective,instead u have to dismember ur enimies to kill them.
every death is full on gore and the blood is everywhere.
onto the pros and cons

PROS
-lots and lots of gore
-stunning graphics
-great,gripping story
-in space
-lots of explosions
-great multiplayer
-great shooting mechanics
-great gunplay
-great horror
-great creepy atmoshpere
-very jumpy jumpscares(especially at night with your lights off and curtains drawn with sound cancelling head/earphones and full PC volume)

CONS
-a bit laggy
-only a few bugs but still

OVERALL RATING
dead space 2 is one of the finest horror games ever made but multiplayer took the horror and swapped it to action but fun action but above all the cons i would give it

singleplayer:9.4/10
multiplayer:8/10

thanks for reading and thumbs up

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 takes place in 2511 on Titan Station, also known as The Sprawl orbiting Saturn's largest moon. It's been three years since the events of the first Dead Space game. CEC Engineer: Isaac Clarke awakens in a hospital, suffering from hallucinations of his troubled past. During his awakening, the civilian space station is subsequently plagued with a deadly alien outbreak little to be known as the Necromorph infestation. The living, breathing, nightmare encountered previously has made a return for the worst. It's up for Isaac, as well as a small band of survivors to put a stop to this, once again.

Along the way Clarke battles his inner demons caused by widespread dementia. The effects caused by a man-made artifact with alien origin, known as the Red Marker. Dead Space 2 has an incredible atmosphere. Although the storyline within the sequel isn't as deep or intriguing as the first installment, this by anymeans does not halt the experience. The length of the campaign is reasonable, most will find themselves spending a fair share of hours collecting data and enjoying all 15 chapters, slowly piecing the story together.

This series in particular is primarily a thirdperson shooter. Dead Space 2 features a HUD that quite frankly, stands out from most others. The R.I.G. and Kinesis Module can be found on the back of Clarke's suit, while the ammunition meter is shown on the side of your tool or weapon. 360° camera movements are available, so you can watch your guard throughout every dark corner of The Sprawl. This feature is also great for taking professional looking screenshots. The game includes a limited amount of cutscenes, so you're never dragged too far away from the excitement.

The visuals are beautifully done, making the game a real treat to explore. The combat system is pretty basic, although dismembering your enemies can be extremely satisfying. There are no loading screens in-game unless you happen to die, so you are fighting for your survival none stop. The game also includes more character interaction and lengthier dialog than in the previous title. There's also  just as many environments containing puzzles throughout DS2, as there was in DS1 to put Isaac Clarke's Engineering skills to the test.

Jason Graves composed an outstanding soundtrack, the sound design makes the experience so much more effective. If you listen carefully enough while idling you will hear unearthly screeches and survivors whispering; sooner or later this will increase the tension. Zero-G areas in-game have been vastly improved compared to in DS1. There are also a wider variety of unlockables throughout the game. Upgrading your weapons at the bench, or purchasing items from the store is always fun and interesting. If you happen to lose track of where you are going not to worry, the Locator will help guide you through any situation.

Dead Space 2 includes a variety of difficulty modes, both appealing to casual and hardcore gamers alike. These modes include: Casual, Normal, Survivalist, Zealot and Hardcore. Adding more replay value to the game, the developers created an unlockable weapon known as the Hand Cannon. This is available to anyone who completes DS2 on hardcore difficulty.

In DS1 Isaac never spoke, which was tolerable to some extent. However he has now been granted a voice. Clarke reacts more often to scares than he previously did in DS1; this makes a great addition. Gunner Wright does a fantastic job portraying Isaac. Some scenes in DS2 can be fairly emotional, really hitting you at the right times; the player will care about the protagonist, pitying Clarke more so than in the previous game. The supporting cast of characters also do a great effort throughout. As we progress further into the story we learn more about them. Unfortunately for Isaac you can never trust everyone, he learns this the hard way.

Remember folks there's always Peng!


If you're searching for an exciting sci-fi horror experience I suggest you look no further.

reviewText:
9/10
Overview: Survival Horror-Third Person Shooter

The Good:

+Graphics, lighting and atmosphere are fantastic and provide a real sense of horror

+ No HUD makes things more immersive

+ I love that once you gain control of the main character, you never lose control, there are no cut scenes, cgi or anything that takes you away from the character. All the action takes place from the characters perspective and that provides an extra layer of immersion.

+The game provides a great sense of pacing, slowly introducing new enemies, gameplay mechanics, locations and puzzles to keep you second guessing what's around the next corner. In addition the sequel adds lots of cinematic set piece moments that really amplify the tension and action.

+ Variety of weapons each with their own primary and secondary functions opening up new play styles

+ Finding nodes throughout the ship as well as purchasing it in the store allows you to upgrade your weapons and suit

+ Combat has been improved, not only is shooting limbs off enemies satisfying but you can use your telekinesis to rip claws off enemies and shoot it back at them

+ Monsters look, feel and act scary along with good diversity to keep combat engaging.

+ Improved zero gravity section

+ Variety of death animations

+ new game + mode

+ Sound effects and music really add to the tension


The Average:

The game is more focused on action than horror especially as the game progresses.

The story can be hit or miss depending on how invested you are in the universe and characters.


The Bad

- vsync locks frame rate at 30fps

-multiplayer is dead


Conclusion

I have played this game many, many times on the Xbox360 and this is still one of my favorite survival horror games. It does so many things right in the genre. I STRONGLY recommend this game to anybody who either loves survival horror games or third person shooters. I do consider this game to be the best in the trilogy as Dead Space 3 has some really questionable design decision.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is back with more gore and over the shoulder person survival horror in space! This time the almost faceless silent protagonist named Issac Clark is back from deep space, but in this sequel he now has a face and a voice! Is it for the better because he now talks to people? Its not better or worse he's more of a vanilla flavor now instead of being just a mystery like the first game. One quick downside is that you'll need an Origin account. Yep, feel free to hate the game because you need to log in even if you don't actually need Origin on your PC, just an account. Now that's out of the way the people who aren't outraged into throwing bloody feces can read on.

For those that didn't play the first game, you have an optional video recap of the first game and its events that happened. When the game opens, the space station you're on board has already been taken over by alien necromorphs that use dead bodies to mutate them into a variety of creatures.  The game has always boasted strategic dismemberment, so you'll need to shoot an enemy in the legs where it will then crawl after you. Shoot its head and it will blindly swing at you. Its a nice dynamic that really boils down to your aim.

Since the space station is being overrun with creatures, you'll see NPCs fighting for their lives in scripted sequences, but it doesn't break the flow of the game with straight up cut scenes. It feels like you'll always have movement or the game will always be moving forward. It adds to the immersion process. Even if you are not alone, you're the only person that can do anything. The game is beautiful with all of its horrific glory, lighting effects and sheer beauty of space. You get a scale and a scope with this game. You'll look over space apartments, see shuttles leaving and others crashing. You'll walk through a church, and a brightly lit, yet super creepy kindergarten school. It feels like the station is alive where the original Dead Space 1 felt very controlled circumstances, like nothing was happening without you being there in the room.

Is it scary? The game has gone through great lengths to make this game legitimately scary and more tense than the first game. Its not just scary monsters chasing you oh how scary. Its being haunted by your dead girlfriend. The game also manages to put you in a lot of helpless moments such as being in a straight jacket with enemies around or hanging upside down and forced to murder enemies before they reach you (some might call it a turret section with a twist). There are some memorable scenes. Other than that, the game keeps a dark atmosphere with amazing lighting. You still get a flashlight that only works when you aim. Thankfully the developers have really done a lot to clean up the ragdoll problem that had the dead enemies get stuck in the player's feet for laughs.

The controls have improved from the first game, thankfully there are now hot buttons for health, reload and other minor tweaks that feel so much better. For those that haven't played, left stick controls movement, right stick or mouse controls the camera, you have 4 weapon slots to change in the D-pad, an aim button, shoot button, which is also the melee button when not aiming, telekinesis button to pull objects, stasis button to slow objects down while you run by, run button, health button and so on. There's even a stomp button for destroying boxes and when you think enemies are dead, but they haven't dropped any items, so you go over and stomp them for valuable prizes like health and ammo. Thankfully the game's map and inventory have been replaced, with easy to use 'follow the line on the floor' when you push a button and the inventory only appears when you're at a store. The line on the floor disappears, so its not a blunt cheat so much as a brief hint if you need it.

Dead Space 2 takes you through extra steps that Dead Space 1 didn't really touch on to teach and inform you extra ways to use your powers. Such as using telekinesis to pick up and throw items at enemies that seems to damage them more than your guns can.

The station has stores that allow you to sell your items, buy more weapons, ammo, health and suits to wear. Each suit now has a special buff, which feels good and it give you more choice and our hero Issac will have more style! Buffs like weapon X does more damage, more health when you use health packs, more air and so on. You can still find health and ammo in a lot of places. Dead Space 1 and 2 both reward you for looking around, but for the most part if it has a light, there's something in it.

You'll also get energy nodes that you go to upgrade benches and upgrade your weapons, suits, stasis powers and so on with simple to follow upgrade paths. One node per point on the upgrade path and it might take you 3 points to upgrade what you want. Its a nice system. At some point you'll earn the right to resort your nodes so if you've put everything into stasis and air, you won't be screwed in later parts of the game.

The original game was good, but this adds a lot more to the gameplay, such as now in zero gravity areas, you don't just leap from point A to point B in a straight line, now you can jet around.  You can also climb through air ducts in realistic third person fashion and there are also hacking mini games that boil down to, circle the left thumbstick until you find what you're looking for. These might not be ground breaking, but they feel like a good diversion from the norm.

Dead Space 2 offers a lot of new enemies and situations. New enemies that vomit at you, new raptor like humanoids that will flank you and call to each other before charging straight at you, new children, new exploding babies and much more. You'll find new bosses that offer more variety than the original game's bosses. All of the enemies are back from Dead Space 1, but this time the developers have gone through, reskinned old enemies and offered more variety in every creature. It won't just be the same mutated man in a labcoat, it will be a variety of people and genders. It feels good and fresh in what could have easily been just a same old rehash. Speaking of a rehash, while you're in space, you're no longer on a space ship, now you're on a space station that has a lot of different areas, slums, apartments, med labs, and so on. Its all about diversity here.

The game has improved little details such as the arm extension into walls. It just feels fresh while feeling very familiar. There is also tacked on multi-player that requires you to have an Origin account that features 4 players as engineers vs 4 players as enemies. So that's good I guess, but the single player experience is the real star here.

For anyone that truly wants the game it has been on sale for $5 pretty frequently. Give it some time. Otherwise, I'd say the game is worth $20 and I'm cheap.

reviewText:
Recommend for Casual Gamer
Not recommend for Hardcore Gamer

First 3 hours experience:
*Story continue from deadspace 1, but this included short clip about previous episode
*The control feel more accurate than deadspace 1, graphic improve a lot.

After 3 hours experience:
*Nice maps! Futuristic apartments, mall, church, space, I'm enjoy it!

After 6 hours experience:
*Pulse Rifle is the only best weapon to survive, other gun is not helpful...

After 9 hours experience:
*Starting repetitive encounter... But soon, turn to getting exciting encounter!

After 11 hours experience:
*I beat the game! The ending is a bit anticipated, if experienced a lot movie.

Enjoyment: 8/10

+Items reward for beginner create a first EA account
+High quality graphic for 2011 technology
+Easy puzzle, just keep eye open
+Able to switch game difficult anytime (Casual mode is extreme easy!)
+Additional route guideline to store & bench
+More diversity map than deadspace 1
+More weapons & suits than deadspace 1
+Larger torch than deadspace 1
+Less scary than deadspace 1
+Return back to deadspace 1 Ishimura Ship
+Melee attack animation is more faster than deadspace 1
+Extra reward from redeem codes
+Headshot is still not lethal
+Dead body still can dismember
+Useful weapon upgrade
+Ammo can be sell = earn money more quick
+Gameplay Ability: Stasis Module = Make a monster slowmo
+Gameplay Ability: Kinesis Module = Move an object without touching
+Good story, especially on starting. But story been dragged too long, i prefer a short version
+After the end of the story, player is able to restart the game with all upgraded
+No cloud save, that mean able to load other player saved files

-Same dead animation...
-Cant quick dodge
-Monster sound is a bit too loud
-No more map guideline
-More harder to find store & bench than deadspace 1
-No cloud save, need to backup save file manually

GAME MODE:
= Linear story (15 Chapters)
= No Coop mode
= Multiplayer (Manually add EA friend to play 4 vs 4)
= No Steam Achievement

Replay value?
*Recommend for gamer that looking for hardcore horror survival gameplay.
*Player able carry upgraded gear in new game. With prototype suit unlocked.

Worth buying?
*Yes, for normal price; Or wait for sale, there will be 75% off
*No, don't buy if you don't have enough money.
*Is a good collection for horror game fan.

Dead Space 2 is an atmospheric and immersive action-horror shooter set on the Sprawl.  It takes all the aspects that were great in Dead Space and improved upon them without changing the game mechanics that worked well.

reviewText:
This review may contain spoilers: However, I will attempt to limit them to the best of my ability.

In the 3 years Following the events of Dead Space, and Issac's encounter with the Necromorph on the USG Ishimura, Isaac finds himself in the medican facility of a civilian space station surrounding Titan. Repeatedly questioned, Isaac awakens in a straight-jacket as an apparent Necromorph outbreak begins to take over The Sprawl. Jumping right back into the action seat, Dead Space 2 picks up literally with the heart pounding, fast paced action of the original, leaving us to wonder, will Isaac be able to cheat death a second time?

Dead Space 2 looks as good if not slightly better than the original. From the beginning sequences we see some of the familiar Necromorph from the first Dead Space; However, if I know games, I'll put money on new and even more terrifying Necromorph in store for Isaac later on. If you haven't played the first Dead Space, that's alright. Dead Space 2 has a feature to allow new players to the franchise access to a video recap, complete with narration, of the events of the original Dead Space on the USG Ishimura. For the full experience, I recommend playing in the dark, in a quiet part of the house, at night with the sound up. If you love action-packed, sci-fi, horror thrillers, this is right up your alley.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 takes place three years after the events of the first game.
Isaac awakes on a space station known as the Sprawl and finds the place is overwhelmed by an outbreak of reanimated corpses called Necromorphs.
The core combat of Dead Space is pretty much unchanged. Isaac Clarke needs to destroy the Marker (the seed of evil), therefore he has to explore a massive space station, work with various characters and kill a lot of Necromorphs. While the plot is similar, the storytelling technique has changed for the better, Isaac can now speak and the voice performances of him are excellent.
Adding to the overall tension of Dead Space 2 is one of its central plot lines: Isaac seems to be insane this time around. This plays an important role in the story as delusions begin tormenting him early on including a terrifying ghost version of his dead lover Nicole.
Zero gravity mechanics have been overhauled and Isaac is now afforded a full six degrees of motion and able to fly in any direction with his thrusters. One other addition is the ability to hack certain circuit panels, an activity that initiates a quick mini-game.
The mutliplayer mode features a familiar experience system, slowly unlocking new goodies as players level up. Necromorphs acquire upgrades to their abilities, while humans can unlock new weapons and armor configurations.
Dead Space 2 does not stray far from its roots, but it still manages to provide one of the best action horror experiences available. In short, horror fans should definitely get it.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 9/10
Gameplay 9/10
Atmosphere 10/10

reviewText: Those new to the horror genre might get a spook from it, but veterans won't be scared in the least.  It's Western horror, which often has relied on attempts to startle the player and turn their stomach with disturbing images and gore.  However, I couldn't stop playing, due to the fact that your very squishy foes are very fun to blow apart with an array of unique weaponry and tactics.  The game and interface flows beautifully and you will never see a single load time breaking the immersion, aside from getting killed, so the better you do, the harder the game will be to put down.  If veterans of the horror genre are looking to get their fix, this may not deliver, but if it's a survival monster mash you're craving, pick this one up!

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is one of the best games to come out in 2011
DS2 is a third-person horror shooter. I first played through the game back in 2011 just after it released.
The game scared the crap out of me! Seriously. It was the most horrifying game i had ever played.
However the character development, dark atmosphere and gameplay left a very positive feeling to me so i wanted to revisit the game.

Fast forward to January 2016. 4 years after i first played through the game. Graphics still feel nice. Nothing special. It's not on par with the Witcher 2, Battlefield 3, Deus Ex: HR or Crysis 2 (Every single one of these games released in 2011) but it's still a good looking game.
It looks damn good for a dark horror game. The lightning and adventuring in the darkness is done perfectly. The armosphere is still there. The sound effects still sound so very good and the gameplay...Ahhh the gameplay is simply a masterpiece!
However it doesn't feel like a horror game anymore. At no point was i scared in my second playthrough in 2016. Felt like an ordinary third-person shooter without a cover mechanism.
It gave me a few adrenaline rushes when the enemies were coming from different directions and were overwhelming but it didn't actually scare me.
Maybe because i had already played through the game or maybe because im now 4 years older. Tho i'm sure that A LOT of people would still find this scary. After all some people think that F.E.A.R games are scary and i strongly disagree with them.

The game is great tho. The voice acting is very well done. The few characters in this game actually have CHARACTER and the game constantly keeps you in your seat wondering what's going to happen next.
The gameplay is wonderful. You can wield 4 guns at the same time. You can have a pistol, a plasma rifle (an assault rifle) a flamethrower and a line gun (basically a space shotgun) all at once. You can shoot the legs off your enemies to slow them down. They lose their legs but keep crawling towards you and are still quite deadly. The point is that you can dismember your enemies!
There are 10 different guns in Dead Space 2 and each gun has a primary and secondary fire option so when it comes to killing aliens there's a lot of variety.
You can also pick up pretty much everything from the ground and use that as a weapon. You can kill an alien, pick up its blown off arm and shoot it at another alien.
You can also freeze rushing aliens to give yourself more time running away, reloading or dealing with other threats.
You can also upgrade your weapons and suits (yeap, you can buy different armors aka space suits) to give you more damage, faster reload speed, more capacity or more health when it comes to armor.

Dead Space 2, while being a very scary game, is very fast paced to keep you on your toes at all times and that makes this singleplayer experience one of the best in 2011.
Back in 2011 i beat the game using a keyboard and a mouse. Now in 2016 i beat the game using a 360 controller and i gotta say the gameplay is perfectly enjoyable with both of them so feel free to play the game however you want to.
There's also a new game+ mode and a hardcore mode which only allowes 3 saves and whenever you die it ports you back to the last save (That's right! No checkpoints!) but you won't get to try that before beating the game first.

Dead Space 2 is a masterpiece and totally worth its current full prize!

GAME ON!

reviewText:
Now, this is what I call a worthy successor: louder and longer, but at the same time not too different!

When I started the game I thought it would have been a mediocre sequel, but this wasn't the case here, as I was pleasantly surprised with Dead Space 2's quality.

Graphics and music were pretty much similar to the first game's, but in this case that was a good thing, since the original was an excellent space horror.

Gameplay was also very similar to the first, but with some, well received, improvements. Most of all I appreciated the new Zero Gravity controls, in which you had full freedom to move and levitate in open space, whereas in the first one you could only jump from one surface to another.
Of course, new weapons and suits were also added, which was nice, though I ended up mostly sticking with the weapons I had gotten accustomed with in the first game... and I wore a suit that was a lot reminiscent of the first one's also. Old habits die hard, I guess.

The enemies were, too, a lot similar to the original Dead Space's, but some new ones made an appearance as well, most notably a big necromorph called The Tormentor, which chases you for a good part of the game.

The story is good,  set 3 years after the events of the original game and manages to bring the atmosphere to life in a very similar tone as the latter. The game, as a true sequel would demand, is also 3 chapters longer than its predecessor and, while at times it felt a bid dragged, does what it does very well.

What maybe could be described as my only complaint would be the fact that it sacrificed the first's scary and tense atmosphere for more flashy effects and action sequences, filling it with plenty QTE-like battles, probably influenced from the trend created by modern action games, such as the God of War or Assassin's Creed series, which, in itself, isn't necessarily a bad thing, if it wasn't for the horror factor that suffered a bit from this.

In a few words the game became, as I wrote in the first sentence, louder" than the previous one

reviewText:
Overall score? 96/100. TL;DR? Takes the first game > Adds a load of content to it > Continues the story from the last game > Adds in Multiplayer.

In-depth Review:

In the world of Third Person Survival Shooters, this game comes out on top for being both challenging and fun. However, much like the first game, I didn't find it to be all that scary like most people do. Sure, it had it's moments and my heart rate did occasionally jump up drastically in some situations, but overall I think the scare factor for this game, and the previous one is pretty low, but that's nothing I would take off points for.

The story line is pretty much what I expected (Oh noes, they made another marker and became obsessed with the crap because the alien signal told them to. Now Isaac has to go on another journey to destroy it. Sound Familiar?) but even with that said, they added in a few major plot twists and mysteries which made it about 100% more unique.

Re-playability also seems to be better, since there are 2 new difficulty levels, one of which only lets you save 3 times throughout the playthrough, and on top of that resets everything you worked for in the last playthrough, such as weapon and suit upgrades.

Graphics/Visuals haven't improved, but honestly, they didn't need to. I mean, I would have liked them to increase the texture quality on the characters and the various suits that Isaac wears, but It's no big deal.

Multiplayer in this game is also very unique and I would totally play it more, but unfortunately it's quite dead, it's almost impossible to get a full game going unless you have 7 friends to play with.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is arguably one of the best action horror games that any lover of horror genre games should make sure to  experience firsthand. The RPG elements mixed in with the TPS storytelling mesh perfectly with one another to bring an unforgettable sequel akin to its equally great predecessor. That being said, the two games are both good but in different ways: The first Dead Space was more of a creepy horror game with action being its sidekick, while Dead Space 2 is more of a sci-fi shooter with some creepy aspects to it; there was an inverse, but nothing was inherently lost from the overall gameplay. However, your own opinion may vary depending upon your susceptibility to being scared, and this game certainly does not disappoint in that department--The game puts you straight into the shocking, fast-paced, frightening action right from the beginning.

Dead Space 2 also polishes up a few facets from the last game such as a better zero-g flight system and controls, more weapons, and more enemies in order to bring a more expansive, smooth gameplay to the player. Of course, there are still a few funny glitches such as the physics and movements of the many cadavers scattered throughout each chapter; it is almost like gmod decided to visit space in a sense. Also, gameplay is very similar to the first game (as you should expect): smash and dismember everything in your path or be dismembered and eviscerated yourself. Simple survival rules to say the least by Darwinian Standards.

I definitely recommend picking up this game if you liked the first Dead Space. I do not even have to go through the five stages of grief after finishing this game to come to the conclusion that Dead Space 2 easily deserves a 9/10. So keep your eye out" for when it goes on sale in the Steam Store. The only thing I have a problem with is the fact that Dead Space 3 has yet to be released on Steam...so pick it up on console or get yourself an Origin Account in the meanwhile until that fateful day comes if you cannot wait after finishing Dead Space 2."

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 (SP Review Only)
Altman be Praised!
Here we have the Sequel to Dead Space 1:
After unearthing a strange artifact known as the Marker, Isaac finds himself on the Sprawl, a giant space station in orbit around Saturn. Unable to remember how he got here and plagued with demented visions of his dead girlfriend Nicole, he must survive another nightmarish outbreak of Necromorphs as he fights his way towards an answer he hopes will end all the chaos.

In my honest opinion, his Game takes some steps away from the Bare Horror Genre and mixes it with a bit of mass effect's Special effects. (Both made by EA, hmmmm.) its quite an action packed ride albeit a very short one! reviewText:
I don't play many EA games anymore due to their separation from Valve, but Dead Space 2 is definitely a worthy successor to the original. There isn't anything really new gameplay wise, which isn't a bad thing. Basically suit and weapon upgrades, moving from point A to point B, and shooting anything that pops out at you.

The story events take place several years later after the original game and makes a lot of references back to that story so if you haven't played the first one, you're going to be missing out on what happened before.

The line cutter was my favorite weapon in the first game and it still ended up being my favorite in this one, although it was pretty satisfying to stick an enemy to the wall with a javelin.

Another great third-person, horror, sci-fi, action shooter.

reviewText:
After completing it a second time I believe I can fully review this now.

I'll start off by not mentioning the horror, But the story. Coming form Dead space 1 to this the stroy flows through really nicely. Its a great story and like number 1 you find a lot of backstory about whats happening throughout.

The horror. Well In the begining its fantastic. A few nicely put jump scare moments and some really scary mecromorhps get your heart going and you find yourself scouring and survivng the best you can. As a con however near the end the horror looses its edge as it become more action non stop style. But its the end and its expected. The anticipation for the end of the story covers it nicely however and you dont really miss the horror at the end.

The comabt mechanics are spot on. All i can recommend is try using different weapons as much as possible. A lot of people say you will only use the pulse rifle and plasma cutter. But if you buy the other weapons you can have much more fun & they are more effective. Such as the javelin gun (A personal favorite).

Overall Its a 9.5/10 for me.

Highly Recommened.

reviewText: Scary? No. Fun? Hell yes.\nLet me start by saying this is one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. I could spend a half hour just looking out the windows onto the city. But Dead Space 2 can take you from awe to terror in just a few seconds. The necromorphs are grotesquely designed, and the action is perfectly choreographed. Sure, there are plenty of jump out of the closet scares, but I would NOT call this a survival horror game, simply because you're a walking gun cabinet. Necromorphs end up falling apart after a few credits are spent on upgrades. But for the most part, watching your enemies being torn to shreds compensates for those false claims. The hardest thing for me is to identify any faults. If I had to complain about anything, it would be the multiplayer. Although it looks good on paper, I found it to be very dry and uninteresting, as if Visceral missed a few key elements in designing it.

reviewText:
★★★★★★★★ Review Time ★★★★★★★★★★

(Mungkin agak telat reviewnya LOL , game ini keluaran tahun 2011 dan baru saya main kan minggu ini XD)

Game Action Survival Horror dari Developer Visceral Games memang patut di acungi jempol. Kompleks Cerita dimulai dari Dead Space pertama yang sukses mendongkrak pamor dari game ini .  Dead Space 2 menceritakan 3 tahun setelah tragedi Dead Space yang pertama.  Isaac Clarke  (tokoh utama) berhasil lolos dari insiden USG Ishimura yang mana dia bertahan dan melawan makhluk alien yang bernama Nechromorphs.

Isaac Clarke di Dead Space 2 ini memang menjadi tumpuan musibah . Bayangkan, baru saja game ini di mulai, kita akan di suguhkan cuplikan adegan mengerikan dari kebrutalan Necromorphs. Tidak cukup disitu saja, di pembukaan game ini kita pun harus survive dari kejaran Necromorphs dalam keadaan tangan terikat. Belum lagi game ini disuguhkan dengan Kualitas grafik , detail karakter dan lingkungan , atmosfer , dan soundtrack yang membuat anda lebih baik diam di tempat daripada melanjut kan misi >_<

Necromorphs berbeda dengan zombie menurut saya, biasanya di game game yang lain anda cukup menembak kepala saja. Berbeda dengan Necromorphs, menembak kepala saja tidak cukup, anda harus memotong dan menghancurkan tubuh dari Necromorphs itu sendiri XD .

Necromorphs di Dead Space 2 ini juga bervariasi, ada yang lambat dan memiliki damage besar, ada yang memiliki kecepatan yang bahkan membuat anda kewalahan mengahadapi nya, ada yang berbentuk mekanisme seperti bom dan ranjau, dan  ada yang mampu menembak kan zat asam.

Di Dead Space 2 ini anda masih bisa membeli beberapa ammo, armor, health pack dan  senjata dalam melanjutkan petualangan selanjutnya. Anda cukup mengumpulkan coin dari hasil membunuh Necromorphs atau mendapatkannya dari menjelajah ruangan. Tidak cukup sampai disitu, Dead Space 2 juga ada sistem Upgrade, seperti Upgrade senjata, health dan lain lain. Anda cukup mengumpulkan power node yang berada random di ruangan atau membeli di Shop .

Armor di game ini layak nya seperti di game RPG, karena setiap armor memiliki efek dan fungsi masing masing. Ada yang menambahkan efek ke Health, ke Weapon atau ke Armor itu sendiri.
Weapon di Dead Space 2 ini pun juga bermacam ragam, ada Plasma Cutter, Heavy Duty Detonator, Agility Rivet Gun, Forged Line Gun dan masih banyak lagi.
Oh iya, dalam menggunakan Weapon ini juga ada beberapa mode, mode normal hanya menembakkan seperti biasa, dan mode Space. Ketika anda menggunakan weapon, cukup tekan tombol Space, dan mode dari weapon akan berubah dengan sendiri nya, seperti contoh Forged Line Gun dalam mode normal akan menembakkan listrik , dan ketika mode Space, akan menembak kan ranjau listrik yang akan meledak dalam beberapa detik.

Untung nya di game ini di lengkapi dengan Locator yang dapat menunjukkan posisi Save , Bench (Upgrade), Shop dan Objektif selanjutnya . |Setiap arah dari Locator ini dibedakan dari beberapa  warna  seperti warna biru menunjukkan Objective, kuning menunjukkan Shop, Ungu menunjukan posisi Bench, warna hijau menunjukkan posisi Save Station
Percayalah , Fitur ini amat sangat membantu kita dalam menamatkan petualangan Isaac Clark.

Selain itu masih ada fitur yang menjadi tambahan dalam game ini. Yakni Gadget Kinesis. Fungsi dari fitur ini adalah dapat mengangkat benda benda, tubuh  dan objek lain nya ke udara, juga dapat melemparkan ke arah yang kita mau. Nah, inilah yang menjadi Weapon cadangan. Jika anda kekurangan Ammo, anda tidak perlu cemas. Cukup cari berbagai benda, seperti besi tajam dan angkat menggunakan Gadget Kinesis dan lemparkan ke Necromorphs.
Juga ada mode modul Statis. Fungsinya apa? Fungsi mode ini dapat memperlambat gerak suatu objek. Misal pintu Lift, cukup anda tembakkan , dan otomatis Pintu Lift tadi menjadi lambat pergerakanya. Mode ini juga berguna sekali dalam misi, misal anda juga kekurangan Ammo, cukup anda tembakkan modul statis ke objek itu, maka Necromorphs akan bergerak lambat. Disinilah action Punch dan Injakan dapat membunuh Necromorphs.
Puzzle juga ada di game ini, gunakan mode Gadget Kinesis dan modul Statis agar mempermudah anda menyelesaikan puzzle tersebut.

Visual efek yang menjijikan, Soundtrack yang membuat ngilu kaki untuk melangkah, mekanisme gameplay yang cepat, Panorama Luar Angkasa dan Futuristik yang menjadi nilai tambah game ini, Rentetan Story yang ciamik. Game ini sangat WORTH untuk dimainkan bagi anda pecinta horror game yang ingin memiliki pengalaman berbeda.

Nilai dari saya 9/10
Info :  Pertengahan game sempat membuat membuat saya Pusing dan Mual. wkwkwkwkwk XD

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is a great survival horror experience that I feel like I should recommend to my gamer friends, but why do I say so?

First of all, it's a survival horror, which is quite a rare genre these days, but that doesn't influence my recommendation, I am merely stating this fact for you to keep in mind if you were searching something like this.

I finished the game in roughly 14 hours or so, with a good pace, exploring everything and playing at the survivalist difficulty, which is one grade higher than normal, as I saw in the forums, it is the best difficulty for someone wanting a challenge, instead of the highest which is zealot and is recommended for new game+.

The challenge was good, I was tense most of the time, never mind the jump scares, the ammo was pretty scarce and the enemies needed only two or three hits to take you down, and all this considering careful ammo and inventory management.
I did end up with a surplus of health kits that I saved in my safe and sold all the stasis packs, but the ammo, I had to buy some of those.
The gameplay is smoother from the first Dead Space, the character controls well and behaves like he should, which means you're not agile but you're not clunky either, it is a fine balance, although sometimes I wish I could roll out of the way I admit (which is not possible for the record).
The horror part and the environment were pretty well done, I never did scream or anything, it wasn't that terrifying, but I was tense most of the time and the occasional F*ck" did come out of my mouth when confronted with jump scares or close encounters with numerous enemies. Which reminds me

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is a terrific follow-up to Dead Space. The game looks very good & this time depth was given to the lead character Issac, which was a ballsy move considering he never spoke in the first game and we seen his face once, but in the end it payed off remarkably well. Even more terrifying than the first game and a welcome introduction of more horrifying creatures, the game had me tempted to turn down the difficulty just to calm the nerves.
Multiplayer is very bad and I would nearly prefer if it wasn't there at all, it can be exscused because its single-player, which its made for, it so excellent.
There was something in the original that makes me prefer it but this is an amazing follow-up to an amazing game.
8/10

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is in some ways a big improvement over it's predecessor.

- The controls in DS2 are much more fluid and reactive. This was one of the biggest downfalls of the original. Good job.
- Isaac actually talks in DS2 so you get a sense of his personality instead of playing a mute character. Good job.
- Removed the overly obnoxious heavy breathing of the no-oxygen areas, and cleaned up the zero-gravity areas to be more fun and easier to control. Good job.

Overall though, the first DS offered a stronger atmosphere and sense of helplessness than DS2, which surprised me a bit. Also the way the chapters are done in DS2 didn't seem to make much sense or have a rhyme or reason. For example, you could just crawl out of a vent (with nothing major happening to advance the story) and you just randomly entered a new champter. How does crawling out of a vent trigger a new chapter? It wasn't really a big deal and didn't effect the game, but it made the game feel like it was lacking direction.

I felt like DS2 suffered greatly from poor character development. DS1 actually had decent character development and I had a pretty good sense of their personalities. DS2 took a step back from that.

The gameplay is nearly identical to the first one with the addition of a few new items you can use kinesis on for combat. I was hoping for some really cool boss battles, but I was disappointed once again (I feel like EA could be so creative with these monsters that they could make some insanely cool boss fights. How did this not happen?).

In some ways DS2 was better than DS1, but in other ways it took a step back. While the game is somewhat fun and I recommend it, I don't think it is the strongest franchise. DS2 takes about 12-15 hours to complete.

7.5/10

reviewText:
First of all the actual game is awesome! It's a really great story that mixes strange religious cultism with horror, and leaves enough of the backround ambiguous to make it mysterious. The game also runs silky smooth on PC, and is a far better port than the original was. The link in with EA has been HIGHLY exaggerated also. Literally all you have to do is sign into an EA account, which many people probably have if they own a console, or have ever used Origin. It's really not as big a deal as everyone says.

The two major flaws however are as follows:

1) You can only install this game a certain number of times so be carfeful not to uninstall unless you're finished with the game. It wasn't a huge problem for me as I got it on sale and only planned to do a quick run through, but for people who like to, you know, KEEP WHAT THEY FREAKING PAID FOR, or are just struggling with HDD space it may be a problem.

2) The second flaw is kind of mind boggling. They must have included all the DLC for free with the game, because when you hit the very first store in the game you get access to all of the weapons and armour in the game straight away. Again this wasn't a big deal for me as I had already played this game on console and this basically gave me a free NG+ to run through the campaign, but I can see this seriously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ some people off, especially new players.

All in all the game is great, and if you have no problem with the gripes i've mentioned then you may as well get it. However maybe if you've never played it before, buy it from origin as the DLC may not be included there, and you might get the full normal experience.

Game - 9/10
This Version  - 7/10

reviewText: Dead Space 2 is a worthwhile sequel that continues the story of Isaac Clarke and his  fight against the necromorphs. The locales are more diverse than the first game, but the atmosphere is still reminiscent of the original game's dark and creepy corriders. Dead Space 2 also has one of the most gut-wrenching scenes in gaming history where you...Well, it's towards the game's conclusion. I'm sure you'll notice it when you come across it.

reviewText:
Dear Dead Space™ 2 review reader,


The Dead Space™ 2  game will be forever imbedded into my brain. No regrets buying it with the combo game pack (along with Dead Space™ ) FOR PC.

I had the intention of playing it with the upgraded plasma cutter from Dead Space™ 1, however, am still clueless if DS2 managed to detect and include that information into the in-game store. Nevertheless, I started the game in anticipation with the memories of my experience with DS1; on Zealot mode. No less. No necromorph is going to come up and shake my hand in any difficulty, so what the heck, right?

As a graphic art enthusiast, the fluent user interface of the menu/ingame, colour scheme, stunning artwork on buildings and scenery, character a.i. and attention to detail (especially object animation and interaction) was the cream of the crop for me. From the hours spent on developing the game, you'd  know  that they loved creating it as much as you will love playing it.

As usual, the game starts off with an action-packed bounded sequence which really gets the blood flowing. If you had had a break from DS1 after a while... this will just jolt you back into reality". Absolutely love the way developers give you a moment of silence now and then with the chills going down your spine while you raid and explore the beautiful Titan Station. Where there are necromorphs... you're definitely to be on the edge of the seat the whole time... forgetting whether you have  collected that stasis pack at the corner or checked that inconspicious pile of janitorial equipment at the medical deck of the  USG Ishimura .

The storyline is particularly intriguing and at times
date: marvelling with unexpected twists.This game is action-packed (sometimes crazy overly)
recommended: horrifying and gruelling at times. It ends in the most  cheapest bossfight imaginable... but absolutely DOABLE . Remember

never... ever.... give up..

reviewText: Like it's predecessor, Dead Space 2 takes place in a horror survival scenario where Isaac Clarke, our protagonist, must combat multitudes of enemies using his weapons, the surrounding environment, and even the sharp appendages of defeated enemies to survive. Unlike in the predecessor, Isaac Clarke (whom had rarely if not ever spoke in Dead Space 1) was now fleshed out and given a personality (and an enjoyable one at best). The gore is still everywhere in this game and it lives up to Dead Space 1. The game has about 10-12 hours of gameplay with replayability in it's NewGame+ and Hardcore mode, where you only get three saves and barely enough health and ammo to live. Give this game a go if you have a bit of extra money in your wallet, you won't be disapointed.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is a pinnacle of horror meets space experiences.Short answer:  You must have it

I've now played Dead Space 2 twice, once on console and once again here and it felt just as breathtaking as when I first popped the disc into my 360 a few years ago. A timeless experience that will have you staring wideeyed and open mouthed. It may be the first time you curse at the necromorphs on the screen along with Isaac as you fight your way through 15 chapters.

What's changed since Dead Space 1?
Better controls.
More details graphics.
More weapons, and improvements on current ones.
A boatload of amazing cutscenes you won't want to miss.
A very flushed out story that explains more about the Marker, Earthgov, and the Unitologists.
The only complaint, if it's even a complaint, is I wasn't as afraid. But this is the second game, I know where to look and what to expect. If you're looking for fear, you're going to get excitement and thrill. Perhaps this is a fear I'm accustomed to, I don't know. It didn't hinder my experience, but I did walk in having some expectation of fear, but I was given the best roller coaster, toddler stomping, baby blasting, necromorph head punching time of my life.

reviewText: This game is great! It takes place shortly after the events of DS1 and Isaac still can't catch a break. On top of being thrown back into the nightmare, you watch Isaac slowly lose grip with reality. But then again, who wouldn't under such dire circumstances? The story is further delved into, and the transitions are very smooth. I feel the game handles even better than the first one, and I didn't have any issues in DS1. The game doesn't add a lot of new elements, but why change things when the first one was so good? The game is beautiful, in a a creepy and grotesque way. You visit may different and interesting locations, and you are scared all the way through. There are some very tense moments that can be disturbing for some. Overrall, Dead Space 2 was a great continuation to the first game. Someday when I get the courage I know I will play Dead Space 3.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is set three years after the events of the first Dead Space game. The game follows protagonist Isaac Clarke's fight against a new Necromorph outbreak on the Sprawl, a space station above Saturn's largest moon, Titan.

The game incorporates many aspects of the original Dead Space game that made it such a classic, as a result some may consider the game Dead Space 1.5 rather than Dead Space 2. However, this is not a bad thing. The original game was great and as such, Dead Space 2 fills the large shoes of its predecessor whole and completely. As for the plot, I found it engaging which allowed me to connect with Isaac Clarke and his perilous quest. The gameplay was a smooth and enjoyable experience. In addition, Dead Space 2 was successful in creating a world that left you feeling alone and just one step behind the atrocities of the Necromorph outbreak. The subtle rumblings of a necromorph above you or the eerier silence when entering a new room provided just enough tension to make you jump out your seat when a necromorph jumps out at you.

If you thoroughly enjoyed the first Dead Space, Dead Space 2 will not disappoint.

reviewText: The first thing I want to say is that I was personally disappointed with Dead Space 2. I didn't like it as much as I hoped that I would, BUT this is not because the game is low quality. In fact, the game is very well made. The reason that I was unhappy is that DS2 really veers away from horror to focus on action, and this was the exact opposite of the direction that I was hoping for. I had hoped to see an even tenser, sharper-edged survival horror than the original.\n\nThe second thing I want to say is that DS2 is really a very good action game. It has meaty weapons and interesting enemies set in diverse locations. The atmosphere is immersive, but lacking in tension. There is a fairly interesting backstory to the game, so exploring is definitely worth your time. That being said, this is not a horror game anymore. It is more like a blast disturbing baddies with force guns" game. This is not necessarily a bad thing
date: just be aware of it. There are unsettling sections in the game
hoursPlayed: just marginally unnerved.\n\nThis brings me to what I consider the most underused idea in the game: Isaac's dementia and hallucinations. Without going into spoilers
voteText: I found this to be a fascinating idea and was really excited about it in the beginning. Unfortunately
helpfulPercent: the idea rapidly devolves into just a repetitive series of similar hallucinations. It felt lazy. To me
votesHelpful: it seemed like this mechanic could have been used to totally undermine Isaac's (and the player's) sense of reality. The hallucinations could have gone so much deeper
votesTotal: but it turned out pretty superficial
votesFunny:
except for...

MILD SPOILER ALERT WEEEeeeeWOOooooo MILD SPOILER ALERT


... one particular scene
commentsCount: near the end of the game
column16: where "Nicole" is sitting at arm's length from Isaac
column17: and she asks him to touch her. He replies
column18: "I don't think that's a good idea". In my humble opinion
column19: this is one of the great scenes in games. It's simple
column22: yet horrifying. It hints at the seduction of madness at the same time as really telling us something about Isaac's personality and regrets. There are a few moments like this in DS2
column23:
and I consider them the best parts of the game.

END SPOILER WOOOoooooWEEEeeeee END SPOILER

Basically

column25: BUT it is definitely worth playing and you may very well love it. I mainly was disappointed because of my own expectations. This is a very solid action-horror
column26: with a lot of spectacle and a number of thrills
column27: just expect it to be heavy on the "Mad Max with Zombies in Space" and light on "A Tale of Two Sisters".\nI give it an 8.5/10 and a slightly cautious recommendation."

reviewText: Simply amazing. Let me put it at that. One problem with the first game that I didn't like was the fact that Issac never actually talked. reviewText:
This was my first AAA purchase, i bought it years ago on the 360, back when i was a console peasant. This was, is, and always will be a favourite of mine, not too puzzling, dificulty scales well, still quite spooky, and smoth combat that is rarely interupted, but makes great use of hitboxes. Ragdoll physics and gib physics cobine almost seamlessly, along with excellent responsiveness to one's intended target. AKA you shoot leg, leg gets cut off where you shot it and ragdolls instantly. This game may also have inspired the, dare i mention it, death fetish tomb raider, better known as tomb raider 2013 however. Language, though not censored, is nowhere near oppressive and is taken in great moderation without sparing the story of emotion. gore, well, i mean if you're playing a zombie horror game but not wanting to see any gore you must be doing it wrong. on the topic of zombie horror, however, DS2 manages to capture the classic feeling of fear that comes with the collapse of society due to an outbreak, but also manages to make the zombies themselves terrifying and wastes no time plunging the player into a high-octane hook showcasing some of the creatures while instilling the initial fear into the player. Tutorial is simple and unobtrusive, albeit drawn out just a bit long (if you consider the first store the end of the tutorial) but does it's job better than most, if not all AAA titles these days, teaching the player how to use the more tactical and less practical skills to ensure that they can learn how to combine them with gunplay and running for your life for an effective strategy later in the game.
overall, 8.75/10
PC port needs a little bit of bug fixing after all these years and the multiplayer felt like an ever so slightly poorly executed version of L4D2, at least on the 360.
-EDIT-
the minimum system requirements are way above what you will need to play, i managed a solid 40 FPS average on a 1.7 ghz processor, far less than their suggested 2.8

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is set three years after the events of the first Dead Space game. The game follows protagonist Isaac Clarke's fight against a new Necromorph outbreak on the Sprawl, a space station above Saturn's largest moon, Titan.

The game incorporates many aspects of the original Dead Space game that made it such a classic, as a result some may consider the game Dead Space 1.5 rather than Dead Space 2. However, this is not a bad thing. The original game was great and as such, Dead Space 2 fills the large shoes of its predecessor whole and completely. As for the plot, I found it engaging which allowed me to connect with Isaac Clarke and his perilous quest. The gameplay was a smooth and enjoyable experience. In addition, Dead Space 2 was successful in creating a world that left you feeling alone and just one step behind the atrocities of the Necromorph outbreak. The subtle rumblings of a necromorph above you or the eerier silence when entering a new room provided just enough tension to make you jump out your seat when a necromorph jumps out at you.

If you thoroughly enjoyed the first Dead Space, Dead Space 2 will not disappoint.
