reviewText:
This game is effectively the same as the first gameplay-wise with a few tweaks. There are a some new weapons and the game rewards those who use stasis in combat, i.e. me. There are also new enemies. Some which are more challenging to deal with as the can projectile vomit acid and liquid nitrogen over 100 meters with stunning accuracy.

Design-wise, this game is much more linear. You will feel more like you are stumbling through a bunch of set pieces instead of navigating your way through a ship to achieve a task.

One aspect you may find jarring is that Issac now has a voice. It's not that bad in the long run. Although the cutscenes and dialog remain unskippable.

All-in-all a good experience. You may find some answers behind the marker and necromorphs, but there is still plenty of mystery left.

reviewText:
The biggest con of this game: The gameplay. Don't get me wrong, it was fun, but fighting off necromorphs got tiresome. Concentrating fire on armies of limbs coming at you starts feeling more like a way to simply delay the game's progressing story & dull the gameplay fairly quickly.

That said, I did find myself sucked into the game's world (gasp!) & Isaac's now responsive & character-driven story. The environments were far more varied than they were in the first game's depressing series of hulls & hallways & creaking pipes, w/ nurseries & homes & districts full of stores every which way. The cinematic feel was a lot more developed than the first, & I personally love those touches, where control of the protagonist seemlessly disappears or lessens w/ you hardly noticing as the train ye're on comes to a crash or a Space Helicopter™ springs up out of nowheres poppin' caps in ♥♥♥♥♥es' asses.

Better than the first in every way, & I'm sad I put it off so long. Also, screw EA, &c.

reviewText: While I believe the first Dead Space was far scarier, given that you're on a floating ship out in the middle of nowhere trespassing through dark, narrow corridors mostly in silence, Dead Space 2 is fantastic in its own right, with beautiful environment design, a deeper, more invoking storyline, and (my favorite!) less irritating zero-g sections. While in the first game, you were fighting to survive, this time you're fighting to save your sanity as well, which admittedly reduces some of the tension and terror of the necromorphs, but adds on an emotional layer that felt fitting and necessary in Isaac Clarke's story.\n\nGreat game, 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is a great horror game and a brilliant sequel to the another great horror game.

Set, I believe, three years after the events of the first game, Isaac Clarke wakes up in a psych ward in a hospital in a space station, just as the infection that wreaked havoc on the Ishimura (space ship) from the first game breaks out on this space station. Clarke makes his escape while having hallucinations but is also guided by a stranger. This is where the story really kicks off. Because I'm going to avoid giving away any spoilers, I'm just going to say that the person you hallucinate throughout the game is Nicole, Isaac's former love interest from the first game.

The brilliance of the horror elements in this game is that it isn't a jump scare type of game. It's genuinely terrifying because of the extent of damage done to this space station due to a breakout in the disease that transforms the people into these abominations of creatures. The most memorable part is, arguably, when you're in a nursery and you see a woman, still alive, trying to cradle her baby, who has visibly transformed. Well, the baby has a yellow, soft belly and if you've played the first game, you'll remember that the yellow areas are weak points prone to explode. You can probably guess what happens to the woman.

The soundtrack is nice but the game really shines when there isn't any music at all. Just the vast void of sound is so profound and the slightest creak will catch you off guard. The sound mixing in this game is done expertly. The graphics are stellar. I mean, I can tell it came out in 2011, but the lighting is so great and the textures on the walls and characters are generally fantastic. All around splendid job on graphics. The level design is done well enough where each chapter has a varied design. I especially loved the zero gravity flying around in space. The vastness of it, and being able to see Saturn in the distance (I'm pretty sure it's Saturn) is just so unique.

Anyway, I feel like I've said enough. Really, fantastic game. Highly recommend.

9.3/10

reviewText:
A terrifying game, it's jumpscares are very predictable, yet they still manage to keep you on the edge of your seat.

It has you checking every corpse in sight with a ranged gunshot to make sure that they're not going to reanimate and slice your body apart.

The horror within this game cannot be described with mere words, videos and images are enough to keep you on edge, but being inside the game immerses you to the point where you almost emulate the fear that the player is enduring, a truly shocking experience.

You play as Isaac Clark(e?) in the aftermath of Dead Space 1's events, you are lead to believe that you have a mental issue which can be cured if you listen to who is talking to you, both Isaac's ambition to survive the odds given rise to by these messages and your own ambition to run through the blood still keeps you going through the game, despite the offputting level of horror and terror.

Excruciatingly terrifying at a certain point where Isaac re-enters the USG Ishimura, only to be met by a swarm of unstoppable necromorphs which swarm him like wasps, the paranoia you feel when you hear a distant necromorph, thinking you've killed them all, and you think they're too far away to reach you in time, but just as you go to run, it's fangs are buried in your leg is undescribable.

Most definately a game that gets you thinking; you constantly run in to obstacles which enable you to use your mind to utilize many game mechanics such as Telekinesis and freezing, you are able to freeze certain obstacles in time to ensure that they don't slice you in to millions of pieces as you crawl towards your objective.

Do I reccommend this game? absolutely! but it is not for the weak of heart, nor for those who find themselves constantly ragequitting in every game they play.

Watch your step, don't turn around unless you hear a ♥♥♥♥ing noise, and most certainly never think that you're alone.

reviewText: Having never played any Deadspace game, it felt reminiscent of Half-life and the Alien film smashed together. The atmosphere and environment art was stellar, filled with detail, dynamic lighting and smoke effects. It's not too scary or predictable, though there are some jump scares.  Most of the tension comes from the spooky music, the way the enemies move, and how danger suddenly spawns or flanks you. There's also some great gore scenes. The combat was very satisfying, and it was unique to focus on dismembering limbs and stomping on stuff instead of doign flat contact damage.  Overall, it is a very well put together game.\n\nThe parts I didn't like were that enemies pop up unrealistically close to you, and is often what's scary - that something loud and dangerous is suddenly right next to you.  The weapon system was a little overwhelming because of all the options. You ride in upwards of 100 elevators and manual saving felt tedious as the game went on. Some of the story was nonsensical - worthy of being made fun of.  There's some gravity gun-esque gameplay that felt tired and out of place, and sometimes you have to mash a button to get away from an enemy.

reviewText:
I bought the PS3 edition a year or two before purchasing the PC ported game. After worrying for hours how it would play, smoothly or choppy, on my ASuS laptop...

The game worked beautifully and dare I say even faster on here. The game has a lovely story as always, and after quitting the PS3 edition because of hatred to the controller gameplay, I am happy to say I will perservere and finally beat this god damn game. Here's the pros and cons:

PROS:

- Interesting Story
Isaac Clarke has been admitted to a psychiactrics ward where he must escape. But beyond there, it's a terrifying        nightmare that pushes your tolerance to the ultimate limits.

- Great Graphics
Even for the worst computers, the graphics really stand out and work well for the game. The characters, being the most important in terms of detail, are stunning to say the least.

- Weapons
Every survival game needs weapons. Well, except for Outlast™ and a few select others. Anywho, the weapons really stand out and are unique. They a small part consists of makeshift weapons, such as a surgical lazer and fire extinquisher. the rest are things like pulse rifles and spear guns, which are really cool as well.

- Save, Shop, and Store Stations
This game would be horrifically hard without the features you find repeating in the areas of your journey. These are of course the save station, the item shop, the bench, and the numerous stasis chargers you find. The save station is pretty self explanitory, being where you can save your game. The item shop is where you can store items, buy items, and sell items. It's really needed for a game of this stature. The bench is useful too, giving you a place to upgrade armor and weapons, kinda like the enchanting table from Minecraft™.

CONS:

- Glitches
Every game has glitches, it's unavoidable. Even then, this goes in the list. I haven't run into many, but a few have been tht I found enemies stuck in walls and scenery, and falling through elevators happened on one rare occasion. Even then, it doesn't break immersion and this isn't that bad. It's actually kinda.. funny.

- Multiplayer
I know whatcha thinking; Dood. How cud multiplayar b bad!?". Well
hoursPlayed: or the entire thing itself. It's the lack of people. If you want to buy this game
voteText: don't do it for the sake of multiplayer. It's not going to work if you randomly match
helpfulPercent: and for that you should get a console release. But if you REALLY wanna play multiplayer
votesHelpful: get a large group of friends (4-8) and then you're set.\n\nI'll update this as I continue playing. Right now
votesTotal: the rating it a 8/10.\n"

reviewText: This game is really fun! You wake up in a mental hospital, because you keep having visions of hot babes, and they mess up your concentration. Suddenly the hospital is under attack by aliens, who have been hunting you for 11 years after you gambled with them and lost, but the fee you had to pay was too much so you made a break for it. Well, they found you after 11 years. You pick up a gun, which looks badass, and you have no idea how to use but it looks badass as I said, so you keep it, and don this EPIC space suit that attracts all the female aliens, but you're too good for them so you have to put them in stasis and break their limbs off. How complicated the life of a space plumber is with the relationships and the gambling and the guns!\n\nYou escape to a huge spaceship, and take shelter there. You meet some more aliens, and believe me this game doesn't get repetitive, since it's not like you shoot aliens throught the game or anything, I mean EA are smarter than that. You meet a woman, with one eye, who claims she can cure you from your hot babe visions. Suddenly, Isaac Clarke (that's you) goes from being a space plumber who always shows his crack while fixing the portal potties to a ladies man and alien hunter (just like how Abraham Lincoln became a Vampire Hunter). The jump scares don't get repetitive and this game is SUPER scary that you will probably get a heart attack while playing it. I highly recommend this game to people who love the ladies and shooting aliens. I DON'T recommend this to people who enjoy shooting aliens over and over again, because that is NOT what you do in this game.

reviewText:
Notice the glaring differences between the cover of this game and the prequel. The first game shows a severed arm drifting into the emptiness. It illustrates the dangerous and desolate nature of space. The second game takes a more 'gamey' approach showing the player in a manly helmet. This should give you a rough idea on how they differ. What follows is a continued comparative analysis because why the hell not?!

One of the biggest issues with the first game was the oversupply of ammo. It was nothing but a hindrance to setting that despondent mood that I was yearning for. This game on Zealot (hardest difficulty available on first run through) does a better job, usually forcing you to micromanage and conserve your ammo by using other methods of necromorph destruction. The lighting is top notch and the sound is great, especially in zero gravity!

One would think these improvements would bump them scary vibes up to 11! Well have they? You've left behind the oppressive, flesh smeared corridors of the first game and been dropped into a more open, relatable environment. If you're wondering if the spritely decor of this game diminishes the levels of suspense driven apprehension you'd be right. Ooo did a toy just ominously roll into view in the next room? Sorry I was too busy investigating this rainbow for missing colours. Rarely did I have a lapse in composure. Only the black as pitch office/cafeteria and a slice off Chapter 10 offered enough atmosphere for me to take a vigilant approach. Furthermore the jumpscares aren't as plentiful as the first game. Less jump scares means better quality scares you say? Nah the lack of originality renders most of them as predictable as the discussion topics of a feminazi night out.

Enough lollygagging about atmoscares!.. or jumpsphere! They introduced some new enemies in this game. From children swarming you in groups like you're the surrogate mother of mankind to enemies looking like a rejected pokemon, stampeding at you head first trying to sell the notion that living on one TM is effective. They sold it alright. While I admire Headbutt in the pokemon world it's the utmost annoyance in this game. Sitting in a corner waiting for the next one to charge is boring. Being aggressive can easily lead to your death as they'll usually one shot you on Zealot. Maybe I'm just bad but ♥♥♥♥ those things! If they managed not to give you an one way express pass to a funeral home, it's likely you banged them up with your super mega awesome range of weapons of which were improved from the first game. 5 or 6 weapons that I found were satisfyingly impactful as opposed to the mere 3 in the first game. Oh and kinesis impalement exists. What's not to love there?

Love doesn't end there though. Once you finish the game you can play through it again in NG+ or restart naked with only 3 saves at your disposal. It's a nifty feature and more games should have it. Now the love ends. Many a time I leaped into vents like a highly trained rat but crawled through them like a centipede with my legs tied together. These vents are used to transition between some levels but to me it smells of a cop out by the level designers. Oh and who do I have to line gun in the face for including disappearing corpses? I earned that loot ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it.

In Dead Space the desolate ship was a vehicle used to portray the eminence of atmosphere while the sequel threw you into a more approachable world. Ergo as a fear inducing chamber in pixel form it pales in comparison to the first but simply as a video game it's a step up from its predecessor and one of the most solid ones out there.

reviewText:
Isaac hunts again

The controls for the PC version of DS1 were awful. The good news is that these have been improved in DEAD SPACE 2 and are no longer the issue they were in the original. (There are still some problems with camera angles when boxed into a corner but these are an irritation rather than a deal breaker.) DS2 also handles zero gravity in a far more intuitive, and enjoyable way, with none of the crazy hopping from one surface to another as in the first game. Now you can move freely, as you would expect. Also improved in DS2 is Isaac’s level of interaction. Now he speaks! This actually improves the experience more than might be expected, as it gives a greater sense that you’re involved in an unfolding story. The graphics are above average quality though not outstanding. The gameplay is improved by the introduction of more varied environments (although this is still very much a corridor shooter), and there are still plenty of tense moments when battling with enemies, some of which will be familiar if you played DS1, and some of which are new. When compared with the original DS2 is basically more of the same but with a number of welcome improvements and enhcncements. On a final note: I found it a little easier than the first, but that might be because of the improved controls and my familiarity with the gameplay second time around. Anyhoo, there’s still plenty of nerve-jangling fun to be had. Recommended, especially if you liked the original.

4/5

reviewText: Absolutely awesome game. Some claim the horror elements are completely replaced by action, but that is not true. While the third game clearly goes down the action route, this game finds a perfect balance between action, horror, and story. Isaac finally talks! He's now reacting to things, talking to people, connecting to people, and responding to his hallucinations. It gives the game's narrative a much stronger and believable feel this time around. The gameplay mechanics are largely the same, with some new tweaks and additions here and there. Overall a more refined, intense, and emotional journey than the first.

On the game, if you loved the atmosphere and terror the game oozes with, go with this.

reviewText:
Overall a good game which addresses some of DS1's control and movement issues. However it is less frightening and spooky that DS1 mainly in the replacement computer voice - it sounds like you are in a lift tootling to the childrens department instead of a no-hope you-against-the-world and i'm-not-helping-you computer voice in DS1.

Zero-G is also dumbed down from DS1 with it's i-can't-figure-which-way-up-i-am-recovery-button. Hello? in zero-g which way IS up?? Did gamers get confused and stop thinking in 3D?? Anyway this feels a lot more console based than PC based, but hey at least now I don't have to play WASD...

Graphics have had a slight overhaul as wel as some new and very quick monsters...

It also advances the main story line from the Ishimura...

Overall a good game.

reviewText:
There are some things about this game that i really enjoyed but there are a number of buts too.
Like Dead Space the atmosphere was most excellent, BUT, the journey through the game was pretty-much one straight line. Oh, there were twists and turns throughout to give the illusion of a complicated Space Station etc but essentually you are rail-roaded all the way
The combat is tough, the creatures are scary and vary enough to not get overly predictable BUT some levels are capped by stupid little Quick-Time events that break the flow and apart from the last 2 chapters fights are a simple matter of:
Is this an 'encounter' room/corridor? (You can tell almost as soon as the regularily spaced doors open if this is one of 'those' rooms)
Yes? Clear room No? Keep going
wash rinse repeat  I did not sign on to the cr@ppy EA registration BUT still ended up having ALL the weapons and most of the Armour available to me at the very first purchase booth. There was no point hunting down schematics, it was obviously 'space Xmas' with free guns for all
1st Person with the Oculus Rift would have made this game a heart-stopper BUT it is over-the-shoulder 3rd person which really weakened the experience for meI enjoyed the game. The story and back story was more than enough to keep me hooked in the whole way BUT it really just felt like playing with a 1st time  RPG Dungeon Master... You walk down a corridor to a door
date: then down another corridor to another door
hoursPlayed: then enter a room where X jumps out at you etc etc""

reviewText:
While certainly not Survival-HORROR, this game can put one on edge a little, and occasionally a jump scare will get you. Even if the game doesn't scare you, the story is entertaining and the combat very fast-paced and challenging for a third person shooter.

Have yet to beat the game, so this review will be updated whenI do, but so far I've had a fun, challenging ride. Note: I am playing on the second highest difficulty and only using the starting pistol, so maybe the game is actually a lot easier, but if you avoid using other items and just upgrade the pistol and armor, the game is much more interesting.

Also for those complaining about the DLC items, or new players to the game, do not buy the items in the store that cost $0. They are overpowered for the game and make the beginning sections really boring. Once you get to the point that you find at least one or two armor upgrades, then I'd say the free armor is fair game because it is basically the same thing.

reviewText:
really good game... The follow up to Dead Space does everything better.
It is darker and has a more gritty vibe to it.
Gameplay is solid and at times it will make you sweat...
If you didn't play the first part then you should before giving this game a go.
The story just continues after the first Dead Space,, There is no quite and/or slow beginning, after a brief intro,
where you are sitting and talking about past experiences (Dead Space 1) with your shrink things start to go crazy from the beginning.. Stop thinking, start running for your life in the hell called Dead Space 2.
You will not get a minute to get a breath because in this part of the Dead Space all hell breaks loose straight away..
Graphics are a little better, sound in my opinion the same (good) and the gameplay is awesome..
Highly essential videogame series... I'd rate this about a 8,7 out of 10.
Get this and start playing...

reviewText: I love a good horror game and Deadspace delivered this well with it's first and second games. In both you've got a constant feeling like something is creeping around right behind you at every turn. Cranking up the difficulty Helps with the immersion and so does a good pair of headphones and a dark room.\n\nGameplay wise, Try to picture DS1 but with a few button swaps and polished, less Tanky" Controls. The melee combat gets a much needed overhaul as in DS1 it felt more or less futile. The shooting mechanics are roughly the same

reviewText: Great sequal in one of the best contemporary survival horror series. Dead Space 2 has improved graphics, slight but noticeable gameplay improvements that make combat that little bit more fun--yet that little bit less scary to beat but it's a trade-off that still works. The game's environments, sounds, rooms with flickering emergency power, etc., all as scary as the original. The enemies are very similar to those in the original but that is fine because it makes sense with the storyline and Dead Space has some of the most unique enemies in any game of its kind. AI is still great, unpredictable, and therefore quite scary.\n\nAll in all, this game improves on a lot of what the original already did well. For fans of survival horror, if Dead Space is a must-have, Dead Space 2 is right along there beside it! 9/10.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Dead Space 2 is one helluva sequel. It is indeed similar to the first game obviously, but several new elements have been added to game such as hacking. After the disaster on the USG Ishimura, DS2 now brings you to a bunch bigger place, Titan Station aka the Sprawl a huge metropolis orbiting Saturn.  The necromorphs are back and Issac Clarke is on the run from Unitology and EarthGov. Dead space 2 is also loaded with more weapons and more RIG suits to suit your preference.  However, the PC version includes all DLC except for Severed but many of the DLC suits are available free in the store. So it loses the challenge. There is also a multiplayer mode in the game which I do not recommand buying the game if you want online. This is for the story. Oh, and Issac Clarke has a voice actor now. Get this game, its also much more optimized on the PC. So no mouse aiming issues like in Dead Space 1

reviewText:
I guess a release on Steam is always a good thing for us gamers huh? So much new games, so much info and reviews.
To be honest i expected to beat this games in 3 days because it looked easy. Turns out i was completely wrong and that you can't judge the game on the sole basis of reading a raview of a game.

Playing the game i discovered quite a lot of pro, a heap of stupidly talented gamers, and an overall ability to get it sorted slightly better than the non steam users. Not to say they weren't a heap of people who really didn't want to click the help menu, but a bit less than usual (in ratio, brute quantities were overwhelming sometimes :P)
So Bravo for that, but the most amazing part to me is something else. It's the fact that, especially during the last two days the level of assistance on the game was absolutely... completely... super amazing...

First helpers, of course, were core members of the community, people here since the opening of the game. It was not a surprise to see them helping. But it was to see how much they helped. Friends have been spending a tremendous amount of time in and out helping me, spreading info, monitoring things. I apparently didn't sleep, or had been sleepwalking Plaing this game.

And then, it went even more mindblowing. The last day and a half, most of the time I was playing the game, there were as much answer than questions. I was struggling two days earlier in this game because of the new levels and maps.

A. Big. Thank. You.

Going to play this game some more now. So, shall I take a whisky and a cigar, tonight?

- Evan

reviewText:
I paid $5 for this game but its easily worth triple that amount. Got a good 12 hour campaign on Hard playthrough the first time.  Story is good, setting is great.

The game has great graphics, Awesome lighting effects. The performance is good, maxed out 1080p 8xAA, FXAA Smooth!

Sound is good, (except the staticy female voice, hard to tell what she is saying sometimes) though some sounds are familiar ones with Effects.

The game has some great moments, most of my favorite moments are in Zero-Gravity/and or No Oxygen areas.

Compared to Dead Space 1:
Its not as tense, or suspenseful as the first game. Mainly cause now you know what you are dealing with.  The boss fights were better on Dead Space 1 by far.
The input lag has greatly been reduced from DS1 (a lot better now) and DS2 Hard difficulty doesn't bullet sponge the enemies near as bad as DS1. (also better)

Overrall, I think DS1 was a better game, despite its technical inferiority, but DS2 was a solid entry into the franchise.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: The Dead Space series is one that I have an ambivalent relationship with. On one hand, it is a made that is solid both in its mechanics and presentation. On the other, there is not much that is original or substantial about the experience. While presenting itself as a survival-horror experience, a feeling of helplessness and danger is all but removed by the games lack of dynamism. Enemies try very hard to kill you at every turn with little reprieve, and while the survival aspect is bolstered by the scarcity of ammunition and supplies, the journey becomes frustrating and stressful much more than it does scary as there is very little reward presented when overcoming challenges.\n\nThe graphics are gorgeous and characters are well acted and animated, especially Elly, whose who owes her voice and appearance to Sonita Henry of Star Trek fame. But even these nice touches do little to redeem the derivative, vapid story and tedious gameplay.

reviewText:
There are some things about this game that i really enjoyed but there are a number of buts too.
Like Dead Space the atmosphere was most excellent, BUT, the journey through the game was pretty-much one straight line. Oh, there were twists and turns throughout to give the illusion of a complicated Space Station etc but essentually you are rail-roaded all the way
The combat is tough, the creatures are scary and vary enough to not get overly predictable BUT some levels are capped by stupid little Quick-Time events that break the flow and apart from the last 2 chapters fights are a simple matter of:
Is this an 'encounter' room/corridor? (You can tell almost as soon as the regularily spaced doors open if this is one of 'those' rooms)
Yes? Clear room No? Keep going
wash rinse repeat  I did not sign on to the cr@ppy EA registration BUT still ended up having ALL the weapons and most of the Armour available to me at the very first purchase booth. There was no point hunting down schematics, it was obviously 'space Xmas' with free guns for all
1st Person with the Oculus Rift would have made this game a heart-stopper BUT it is over-the-shoulder 3rd person which really weakened the experience for meI enjoyed the game. The story and back story was more than enough to keep me hooked in the whole way BUT it really just felt like playing with a 1st time  RPG Dungeon Master... You walk down a corridor to a door
date: then down another corridor to another door
hoursPlayed: then enter a room where X jumps out at you etc etc""

reviewText: One of the best games in 2011. And personaly one of the best games in gaming history. Great graphics, perfect gameplay. The atmosphere is a nightmare, in fact is so good that only a few games are standing right next to this great title! Games like Silent Hill, F.E.A.R and the old Resident Evil games. Being placed in a alien planet you don't know what is coming for you, you don't know what is that noise that always follows you, you don't even know what to expect when you approach an other room. There are no safe places and this feeling that always something is behind you or above you will follow you in the entire game! 9/10

reviewText: Dead Space 2 is one helluva sequel. It is indeed similar to the first game obviously, but several new elements have been added to game such as hacking. After the disaster on the USG Ishimura, DS2 now brings you to a bunch bigger place, Titan Station aka the Sprawl a huge metropolis orbiting Saturn.  The necromorphs are back and Issac Clarke is on the run from Unitology and EarthGov. Dead space 2 is also loaded with more weapons and more RIG suits to suit your preference.  However, the PC version includes all DLC except for Severed but many of the DLC suits are available free in the store. So it loses the challenge. There is also a multiplayer mode in the game which I do not recommand buying the game if you want online. This is for the story. Oh, and Issac Clarke has a voice actor now. Get this game, its also much more optimized on the PC. So no mouse aiming issues like in Dead Space 1

reviewText: One of these rare cases where a sequel improves on amost every apect of the original without losing its core. Granted, Dead Space 2 makes you feel less vulnerable and the atmosphere of the original can't really be topped that easily, but the combat, characterization, story progression, character relatinships, enemy designs and attacks, mechanics, visuals and music, they're all absolutely fantastic in this second part. Dead Space 2 is bigger, better in several aspects, it's challenging enough without being cheap on Zealot and Hardcore and it's a hell of a lot of fun. The best thing they did was finally give Isaac a face and voice and went inside his broken mind. The Nicole sequences were always fantastic, especially the latter ones, and the Ellie banter was just great.\nThis is pretty much the refined Dead Space experience, with the exception of the opressive and lonelier nature of the first game's constant tone. I would highly recommend it.

Zero-G is also dumbed down from DS1 with it's i-can't-figure-which-way-up-i-am-recovery-button. Hello? in zero-g which way IS up?? Did gamers get confused and stop thinking in 3D?? Anyway this feels a lot more console based than PC based, but hey at least now I don't have to play WASD...

Graphics have had a slight overhaul as wel as some new and very quick monsters...

It also advances the main story line from the Ishimura...

Overall a good game.

reviewText:
Ohh boy what a ride.

Get ready for a genuinely gripping, gory, and just plain fun hike through the Sprawl. From getting launched into the action and floundering about helplessly in your straightjacket, feel yourself becoming more and more adapted to the bananas hunter/hunted life of Isaac Clark.

By the end you'll feel like a real threat yourself- in spite of the fact that the baddies get more and more bad to match. The pace of this game is great and the escalation is oh so delicious.

Gotta say- I am playing this game in 2015 as I also try out the Star Wars Battlefront Beta- and it is STILL beautiful. Sure, some texture resolutions are a little dated but the lighting design and general atmosphere are sooo good. The artistic design of this game is on point.

10/10 you will never look at vents the same way again

reviewText: The Dead Space series is one that I have an ambivalent relationship with. On one hand, it is a made that is solid both in its mechanics and presentation. On the other, there is not much that is original or substantial about the experience. While presenting itself as a survival-horror experience, a feeling of helplessness and danger is all but removed by the games lack of dynamism. Enemies try very hard to kill you at every turn with little reprieve, and while the survival aspect is bolstered by the scarcity of ammunition and supplies, the journey becomes frustrating and stressful much more than it does scary as there is very little reward presented when overcoming challenges.\n\nThe graphics are gorgeous and characters are well acted and animated, especially Elly, whose who owes her voice and appearance to Sonita Henry of Star Trek fame. But even these nice touches do little to redeem the derivative, vapid story and tedious gameplay.

reviewText:
really good game... The follow up to Dead Space does everything better.
It is darker and has a more gritty vibe to it.
Gameplay is solid and at times it will make you sweat...
If you didn't play the first part then you should before giving this game a go.
The story just continues after the first Dead Space,, There is no quite and/or slow beginning, after a brief intro,
where you are sitting and talking about past experiences (Dead Space 1) with your shrink things start to go crazy from the beginning.. Stop thinking, start running for your life in the hell called Dead Space 2.
You will not get a minute to get a breath because in this part of the Dead Space all hell breaks loose straight away..
Graphics are a little better, sound in my opinion the same (good) and the gameplay is awesome..
Highly essential videogame series... I'd rate this about a 8,7 out of 10.
Get this and start playing...

Dead  Space 1 and 2

Where to start. That they both are excellent survival horror games, that both are filled with immersion and that they both have great narrative and story. Those are just few thing Dead Space 1 and 2 have gotten right.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dead Space 1

Dead Space 1 was very atmospheric and i was scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for the first 4 hours of the game.

+ Lots of replay value
+ Doesnt contain many jumpscares, it rather scares you with its tense and horrifying atmosphere
+ Good story with good characters (nuff said)

Dead Space 2

hoursPlayed:
infinite loading screen)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Something both games have in common

+ Superior sound design (necromorphs sound so damn scary)
+ Excellent survival gameplay
+ Graphics looked fairly good even today when using ReShade graphical mod
+ So much replay value

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Verdict

If you like scary games

reviewText: Dead Space 2 is a third person survival horror as you play as Isaac Clarke, a man who has endured a mental condition who must fight against necromorphs and alien species in attempt to reach Diana. A woman who can cure his mental issue. This game has a decent plot with the feeling of dread,agony and pain. A lot of pain. The shooting is executed nicely, using the Resource Intergration Gear to assist you. The shooting is innovative, including a vast amount of gore for the sensation of horror and suspense. The gore can be a bit overwhelming but it's considered creative and it makes the shooting much more addictive. Dead Space 2 is rememberable for the blood but not for it's emotional characters and gameplay. Some chapters do feel repetitive at times or the objective just felt pointless. The scenery is a bit too bland for me, causing me to loss interest in some chapters. Dead Space 2 had some positve touches of third-person shooting that most games don't bring to the table but I really wish it was more emotional for the story it held.  Sometimes cinematic/emotional touches can uplift the intensity or emotion of a game but they failed to do so. Along with some of the missions feeling dull, they kept you on your feet with amusement being properly used when needed. If you like the sight of blood....or shooting unique creatures in the eyes, you will most likely enjoy this game. If you're expecting anything more...don't purchase it. I'll give it a 7.1/10

reviewText:
One of the best games I played. I played it for more than 10 times now and well, the developers didn't really care for fixing the game. The rubber foam bonus weapon unlock is not fixed, multiplayer could use some text chat and a push talk features. Enabling the microphone by default is annoying. You can hear static, annoying static.

For personal preference, the game could use random enemy spawn similar to Left 4 Dead because after playing the game several times, it's easy to predict when and where the enemies will spawn. With random enemy spawning, the game will be less predictable and different every time you run through a corridor.

For the graphics, it's great. The lighting engine is impressive, but there are some instances they cut corners to reduce graphical load for the console versions. For example, your helmet lights illuminate a totally dark room and it's totally absent in another area.

Other than that, it's a great game and I highly recommend this to everyone.

reviewText:
Ahhh, the Dead Space series.  I decided to knock out the 1st two of the series in anticipation to the announcement of the 3rd.

Dead Space 2 was a GREAT game!  Very fun and worth it's asking price too.  Everything that slowed down the 1st game was fixed in this one.  Better controls, limited to no back tracking at all and better animations.  High production value and it shows.  I do believe that Dead Space 1 was the better experience, but Dead Space 2 was the better game.

No more the silent protaganist as Isaac Clarke now speaks and while I was initially turned off by this it's actually not all that bad.  Additionally, now there's Multiplayer!  Played Left 4 Dead multiplayer?  Then you've play DSMP.  Game on!

reviewText:
Not only is this one of the best games I have played, it has one of the best stories to go along with it, with books and short films (of which I have read and seen all), it really stands apart from the crowd because of this.

The Game-play is unprecedented for its time and is easily one of the most gripping and intuitive play-styles that have ultimately made me love this series, and with Dead space 2 it builds onto the creepy atmospheres and scary environments.

However with the above being amazing it wouldn’t actually be as half good as it is without the music score behind it. It keeps you one edge and sets the mood in the game so perfectly I have freaked out over absolutely nothing when the violins strung a little to hard and made me jump.

Personally, I would recommend a controller for this.

Game-play 9/10
Music score 10/10
Story 9.5/10

OVERALL 9.5/10 - A game that will be worth your full attention.

reviewText:
Horror games nowerdays are very week. Lacking actual fear, aticipation and pure thrills all in one package. Dead Space 2 however will give you all that and more!

Gameplay: The gameplay is a solid 3rd person shooter. You have to react fast and learn skills quicly to surive on hard settings. New enemies mean new ways to kill.

Story: An intresting a deep storyline that contiues were the last game left of. Whilst not as deep or mystic still delivers a solid storyline.

Graphics: Above par and excellently atmospheric feel, with lighting and blood and gore that a epic Horror game should have. Plus an excellent optmised engine. The game used only 30% of my CPU and only one core, amazing to say the graphics are as amazing as they are.

So overall, this along with the original Dead Space are instant classics, both for hall of fame and the pioneer of Horror games.

I give it a 9.8/10

Pro's:
- Explores the old ship, very nostagic
- Just an Epic game

Con's:
- Could use better use of Audio

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 lets you take control of Isaac Clarke again as he tries to survive a space colony on Saturn's biggest moon, Titan.

The games brings a lot more to the table this time. A few new weapons, such as a giant spike gun that impales and  electrocutes enemies. Game mechanics have been tuned up. The game runs a lot more smoothly and melee is much more effective. The suit system returns too, but this time each suit has it's own little bonus, like giving you a discount at the store. They even redid the Zero Gravity parts so you have full control over your character.
A few new enemies have been added, including an enemy that uses cover then tries to sneak behind you.

Overall the game feels like a sequel instead of just a modded add on or DLC. Just make sure as you near the end of the game you are fully upgraded. It has quite the difficulty spike near the end.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I love this game with one major complaint -

It comes with the DLC pre-loaded.

Why is this a complaint? Well, from the VERY BEGINNING of the game, you have access to many different weapons (and I think even armor suits) that you normally would not. Not to mention, it's all completely free.

Now, this is just me, but personally, I do not like having all this extra crap available to me because it really hurts the whole resource management" aspect of the game. And the survival horror aspect in general. The game is simply easier with the ability to get all of these different guns for free.

At least at one point
date: there was a means (albeit convoluted) of removing the DLC from the game
recommended: but it meant reverting to a previous version of the game with less updates/patches. I think that's just stupid. You should be able to disable the DLC prior to starting a new campaign game.\n\nBut despite that
hoursPlayed: this game still gets a "thumbs up" because it's just that good. A great sequel to the first."

reviewText:
Pros
+ Atmosphere
+ Game play is excellent. Very satisfying
+ Had to be very resourceful and patient. (At least on the Zealot difficulty)
+ Good story and voice acting
+ Plasma Cutter is Bae

Cons
- The DLC. Let me explain... The Steam version includes all the DLC for the game which is cool but its all overpowered weapons and suits for single player that are literally free from shops in the game from the very start. Personally I didn't use them for the fact it would just ruin the game for me. It was annoying having to navigate through all the DLC items cluttering up the shops through out the game.
- Crawlers

Overall a great game and one of the best survival horror games I've played. A massive improvement in almost every way over its predecessor (Which was still a really good game).

Final Score - ★★★★☆

reviewText: I've had this game for years but somehow always managed to forget about it. However I'm glad I finally came around to play and finish it because it's a great game. Graphically it's still a good looker, even in 2015 (though the textures on the armor could be a little bit better /nitpicking ), the sound design is amazing and more than once the eeriness was kept by only the music. That said this one isn't as scary as the first one mainly because of two reasons. The first one being is that now Isaac knows what's happening around him (you also know that he pretty much kicks ♥♥♥) and the second one is that in some parts of the game, instead of carefully constructed encounters, the enemy monsters just keep on coming, so it's more action oriented. Another negative aspect is that sometimes the game takes away the control from the player (these are not cinematic but in game scenes) and you can't skip them or do anything at all. Thankfully it only happens a couple of times and they're not long at all.\nSo the question is: would I recommend it? Definitely, even if my review seems harsh, I still enjoyed my time with it.

reviewText:
Great game, keeps you on the edge of your seat. Scary atmosphere, sounds are very startling.
Recommend playing at night alone in a dark room before going to bed for best experience.
Multiplayer is fun, asides from not having an option to disable your voice during gameplay in multiplayer.
Thins can be hilarious if you know what to do or have obtaiend the hand cannon, which is for purely entertainment and no lore purpose.
Replayability is great, i can keep playing and playing and playing.
Storyline is great, almost make a movie out of it.
Plot is also good, expect for some twists.
Design of weapons and levels and enemies and models are amazing.
Fun to experiment which weapon suits you the best, and trying to use a special suit that can give you an advantage with your weapon.
Mobs are different, they all don't act the same way.
Over all, i give this game 9/10. It's a bit short on storyline.

reviewText:
I didn't really like the first Dead Space, the movements were slow, some of the levels were a little too hard, mostly the levels with turrets involved. I spent the most of the play through using the plasma cutter. I even posted a negetive review, about how the story was a bit bland. But after going to the end, I was surprised at the twist at the end, it was refreshing.

But the sequel is so much better! Smoother movements, more weapons, more armor, SO much better zero-g game play. The fast that Isaac is now a vocal character and actually is a character that serves to drive the story forward besides just killing stuff was a little off putting at first, but I got used to it fast. And I have a weakness for totally bad ♥♥♥ ass kicking, super hot girls with subtle british accents, (Miranda Lawson was my weakness), and Ellie is an awesome character.

I'm only on chapter 9, but the fact that you can mow down hoards of deranged deformed children, shot kamakazie babies and make them explode, and nobody asks any questions... just makes this game so far above par it's stupid. Awesome game!

reviewText:
This game certainly has some oddities to it (aka bugs but I wouldn’t' call them bugs), such as DLC content being available in the in game store even though I don't have the dlc which kinda made the start of the game easier as the guns/suits cost nothing which you shouldn't have available. I didn't mind though, it gave me variety in what I got to use so I'm not complaining.

I never even clicked multiplayer and also I only played this game through once so no idea what those add to the game, I really didn't care about those. I will say I really enjoyed this game, it was probably the first game I found genuinely scary in a long time. When you're not getting over run by aliens jumping right in your face and still advancing even after you shoot their legs off (using their claws) you are wandering around paranoid to hell waiting for them to swarm you. Some really nicely done aliens in here that remind me of the raptors in the kitchen on Jurassic Park (film) where you are getting hunted. You can hear them making noises somewhere in the dark and then you see what looks like a head peaking around behind a box but as you go to shoot it runs back behind and sprints off. Damn packs of the things zipping round really fast, leaping over large containers and jumping at you is quite scary.

Some parts got very irritating when I kept dying, particularly when I died after a silly animation scene type thing and had to watch the stupid thing each time. Also I found the end very hard (and at times a bit frustrating) when I kept dying and had to wait for it to load all the time (even with an SSD it wasn't the fastest). I played through on 'survivalist' which I think is the 'hard' option,

All in all I did enjoy this and it was scary throughout and I tend not to find things scary. I bought this in a sale and it lasted about 12 hours so well worth whatever I paid for it. There is game mode+ which would extend it's life, it's an oldish game now so I can't see multiplayer adding anything now. I don't really play single player games more than once but you get extra stuff one new game+ which will add for some people. I never played Dead Space 1 and I felt I didn't miss anything from not knowing the previous story.

See this in a sale, pick it up.

reviewText:
This is definitely a good game. But unfortunately it's worse than Dead Space, I understand why - beating such quality is not an easy task. The atmosphere and core gameplay is still here in Dead Space 2 and tweaked to a certain extent, some things have been improved and honestly I don't have much negativity to say about it, maybe just that it's way too similar to Dead Space? Like it's a bad thing, huh? Enemy variety makes things interesting when you encounter new necromorphs and trying to establish some new strategies versus them.

So, what's worse then? Pretty much everything else. It's not entirely bad it's just sub par or worse than what Dead Space offered:

Very simplistic level design. There's no map this time and it's not even needed there's almost always only one door to enter.
Level transitions are usually a QTE/Action scenes which leaves you wondering where the hell you ended up this time, usually you'll partially understand this by reading logs and/or from random intercom messages from various characters. For example in Dead Space there was a monorail and in the wagon you could see a ship scheme so that you understand better where are you heading right now. In Dead Space 2 it's just a sp@stic (this word is censured, wtf steam?) chaos and you'll never be able to fully understand Isaacs route.
Characters are much less likable and some are stupidly annoying, like one of the antagonists which always spams your intercom with cheesy threats, like NOW IT'S OVER!" or "YEAH
date: NOW IT'S DEFINITELY OVER!" when it's obvious that it's not... All other characters are "meh" as well
recommended: and their further development is rather disappointing. On a plus side Isaac brakes his numb record from Ishimura and now talks

reviewText:
The “Previously, on Dead Space” video is a nice touch, though it reminds me how similar Dead Space 2's premise and gameplay are to the last one. This time Isaac Clarke awakens on a facility on Saturn's moon Titan, three years after the rescue-mission-gone-awry on the mining ship Ishimura, and finds a very familiar situation: Titan is overrun with space zombies called Necromorphs that have set about the meticulous dismemberment of everyone in sight—and he's still having hallucinations of his dead girlfriend.

It also highlights that DS2 is a better sci-fi horror game, in a lot of subtle but important ways. While the plot is similar, the storytelling technique has changed for the better—Isaac has recovered from a bout of Gordon Freeman Syndrome (inexplicable muteness), and the voice performances are excellent. But the real star is the environment: for the entirety of the eight-hour campaign, Visceral does an expert job of making you feel in constant peril, alternating between tingling your spine with unsettling scenery and audio and trying to rip it out of your body by way of horrific monsters.

This is what happens if you play Twister during the space-zombie apocalypse.
New blood

Fighting a Necro is different from other videogame enemies, in that shooting its head is like shooting a grizzly in the foot—it barely slows it down, and just makes it angrier. Picking off limbs takes them down quicker, requiring multiple accurate shots per target—which makes the smooth controls greatly appreciated.

DS2 has a zoo's worth of different varieties of spitting, charging, wall-crawling nasties (including evil space-babies), and each puts up a hell of a fight. The first time I was hunted by the new Stalkers was one of the most frightening moments of the game—I caught a shadowy movement behind some crates out of the corner of my eye, but I found nothing there. I heard a chirping noise, and spun around to see a velociraptor-like creature charging toward me. With a scream it smashed me to the floor, then nimbly darted away, intelligently using cover to escape before I could hit its legs. Then, more chirping—and I realized I was surrounded. Clever girl.

Stalkers are swift, agile pack hunters. Also, they're jerks.

Most of the 15 stages have a unique look to them (as unique as possible given that they're mostly metal corridors), from the wrecked residential areas to the Necro-worshiping Unitologist temple to the EarthGov zone, and they're punctuated by floaty zero-G areas. You have all the same tools as before—the upgradable Rig suit is equipped with time-slowing and telekinesis powers—but the levels are designed well and don't overuse any one gimmick. That includes enemies that must be defeated by blasting their glowing yellow bits.

The new multiplayer owes a lot to Left 4 Dead's example: four human players fight their way through a gauntlet of objectives while four class-based Necro players and AI-controlled backup zombies assail them from all sides. It's fun, and produces some nail-biting finishes, but aside from making you unlock equipment with experience (which I don't personally care for), it doesn't do anything we haven't seen before.

No you idiot, don't shoot it in the head!

Overall, besides retaining the irritation of having to seek out a save station to avoid losing progress when I want to quit, DS2 is a smartly improved version of the original. It's not a new experience, but it's a hair-raiser nonetheless.

THE VERDICT
90/100
Dead Space 2
An excellent action-horror sequel. Dead Space 2 doesn’t try to innovate, but it’s a highly polished alien-rending experience.

reviewText:
More action driven and less scary than the original, but depending on your perspective a potentially more exciting and well rounded experience that improved on the predecessor.

Ultimately it depends on your preference in Horror/Action vs. Action/Horror.  Unlike most I considered the original's most impressive aspect to be the unique enemy design and weapon combat.  While I loved how well executed the monster closet horror was, I didn't find it as monumental as certain psychological horror games like Silent Hill or FEAR, so the change in tone found in Dead Space 2 wasn't a big deal to me and I really appreciated all the subtle improvements to the gameplay.

If your love for Dead Space came from the atmospheric sense of isolation, then you'll probably be disappointed by the frantic and sometimes bombastic nature of Dead Space 2, although it's not completely without it's quieter suspenseful moments.

The heavier story broadens the Dead Space universe similarly to how the film Aliens did for Alien.  That metaphor can be used to describe the stylistic differences to the two games as well.

Regardless of whichever way you prefer, Dead Space 2 is a good game.

reviewText:
Product received for free

The game and the gameplay itself is legit.  Isaac Clarke became a dancer in this game if how often I make him stomp the yard (or enemies if we're splitting hairs here) is any indicator.  The environment and the overall survival-adventure genre gives your heart a steady workout as you play the game, but nothing too drastic to keep you from copping out.

Despite all this however, I would have to give this game review a solid no.  And it's because the programmer for this game thought he was really funny and proceeded to ♥♥♥♥ up the programming or something for Dead Space 2.  More often than not, when you try to reload or respawn, there will be times where you will respawn empty-handed.  As in no weapons, which means not even the chance to perform melee haymakers.  You are straight up walking around empty-handed like a dumbass badass straight into a necromorph thinking you hot ♥♥♥♥ and all that only for you to expectedly get torn a new one.  Yes i've checked my inventory, yes i've tried to reequip my handy-dandy plasma cutter.  Nothing.  You're only option left is to reload the game again (if your dumbass saved while knowing this happened, you might very well have permanently lost that item forever unless you start a new game completely, fully-upgraded or not).  If you have really bad luck when you reload a last save, you might be caught in the loading screen forever until you decide to just quit the program itself and reload the last save (goodbye hours of progress).

But my biggest issue with this game is that for whatever the ♥♥♥♥ reason, EA thought it was a good idea to give the player every DLC weapon/armor at the start of the game, doesn't matter if you started fresh or beated the game.  From the moment you reach the first shop in the game, it's decked with weapons that can fill your inventory and armor that gives some pretty decent buffs.  Whats worse is that all of these DLC are free, no credits are needed.  If you're like me and you like the challenge of grinding through a game and actually earning your upgrades, then this is a serious turn off.  One can suggest to just ignore these free stuff and play the game as is, but the fact that these items exist at all without our say leaves a bad taste to the mouth.  There is a way to manually turn the DLC off through coding, but honestly the fact that you have to go through all that at all just to play a vanilla version of a game is jsut disgusting.

So to sum it all off, ignoring all the flaws that i've listed out, the gameplay overall is still similar to the first Dead Space we all played and enjoyed (or hated, i don't know how you roll).  It's still fun to literally curb stomp the ♥♥♥♥ on not just your enemies, but also dead civilians into delicious chunks.  My recommendation is that you take these complaints into serious consideration (check Google, it's not just me having these problems) and to get this game ONLY if it's on a serious sale or is given to you free.

reviewText: Dead Space 2 is a great game, it is allot of fun to play. That being said I would like to point out some things I didnt like. When you get to the first store the game basicly throws you an upgraded version of every single wepon and armor. Some of you might think that this is awesome, you get every gun in the game for free, but to me it makes the game lose its magic. I first played the game on the Xbox 360 and my favorite part of the game is the fact that you have to be smart with your money and recorces in order to win. I would cary around a contact beam just so that i could sell its ammo for 1,000 credits when i reached the store. Every single time i would reach a store i would change from whatever suit i was wearing into the vintage suit just to make the prices go down, i would make my purcases and then change back to my previous suit. Since i carefully played the entire game like this it made newgame plus so rewarding because everything i had i earned. On this version of the game however i didnt get that experiance. I was basicly handed eerything i had worked so hard to get on the 360. As i mentioned at the begining this is a great game and i highly recomend it, but i wish that the free wepons and armor were only given to you after you beat the game once.

reviewText:
Little Over view Look past all the hate towareds EA (i did before posting this) in a few words This game is AMAZING, but still falls flat in cirtain aspects, my main gripe with Dead Space 2 is that on the easyer difficultys its not very scary because you have lots of ammo and health packs, i highly suggest playing on a higher difficulty that limits thre recorces that you recive making fighting Necromorphs harder when ammunition and health is hard to come by making you leurn how to drop enemys without gut shotting them with the plasma cutter (it is possible to play ONLY using the plasma cutter, ammo is very common for it even on harder difficultys)

Overall Look and Feel Despite this game's age  and style it is very pretty in places when looking out of windows over looking satern when your not fighting for your life
Some of the indoor sections are dark and gloomy creating an atmosphere that is emersive and demands the player to be alert of their sroundings  because you dont know whats going to try and chop your legs off

Comparrison to the original Dead Space In many ways Dead Space 2 is an improvments to the gameplay and story, yet it has partly lost some of its mystery to were the necromorphs have come from, but on the other hand it explains a lot and adds more to the story out waighing the negatives, Newer versions of necromorphs vary the combat making stasis more useful in combat other than just to make an escape in a tight squeeze when your outnumberd or ammoless,  Seeing the Ishimora again braught back happy/tence memorys of Dead Space

Should you play it?YES!, Get this game but i HIGHLY suggest you get the first game aswell because it set up the story for this game (there is a prevausly on dead space" but you would find it better to play though it yourself

What would be your rating?If i was to give this game a rating
date: i would give it an 8.5 out of 10
recommended: there are is a lot of good yet some annoying design decisions that EA have made (such as oragin account needed to play on multiplayer
hoursPlayed: but i consider multiplayer unessasry when the singleplayer is so good)
voteText: dont let the EA stuff phase you from getting this game (you can decline the sign in ever you start the game so it dosent force you like many people say)

reviewText:
Dead Space 2 is an excellent follow-up to what is easily the best new survival horror game since Fatal Frame or Silent Hill, and at the time was definitely the only franchise still bringing the pain. Much more than you can say for Resident Evil for sure. The game features improved graphics, a more thoroughly grounded story that expands both before and after the events of Dead Space to create a living world, and much more action than the original.

That's both a good and bad thing, as DS2 is clearly more action oriented and paved the way for the action game that ended up being Dead Space 3, but at least in this title the survival horror still comes to the surface as much as possible. New space mechanics allow for 360 degree space/zero-g movement, the game is packed with new weapons and old, and it also gives you plenty of new suits each with their own advantages and disadvantages. The whole game is an explosive thriller with great pacing that almost makes up for abandoning most of the horror elements of the original. Even keeping that in mind, Dead Space 2 is a great game that deserves to be called a masterpiece in its own regard, even if it is different from Dead Space.

101/10 would buy again, even though I already have 4 copies.

reviewText:
Ill be brief and simple

This is my favorite horror game ever made

The story is fantastic, the characters are not tired stereotypes that we see in every other horror game known to man, the gameplay is cruel and you have to be ready to fight for your life at every corner, the ending is the best ive ever seen in one of these games, and it does what any good sequel should do, stand out well enough on its own, while still treating the first in the series like the Holy grail of all games ever. This is one every person should own, and Id say play this BEFORE the first one because then the first one is that much more prophetic and revealing if you do it that way. (If you can get the first one to work on your computer, which I cannot)

Yes, this is one you need to own.

reviewText: The decline of the Horror Survival genre into an action shooter with horror elements can be seen in the transition from Dead Space 1 into 2. The Horror elements are reduced to jump scares and grotesque violence, rather than using the environment and our imaginations to install fear. There's less a sense of Isolation and Confusion as your lead by a carrot through hordes of monsters. The lack of any boss battles and over usage of quick time events are other shortcomings.

reviewText:
Pros:
-A variety of unique weapons that allow for slightly varied combat approaches.
-An equipment custimization system that is easy to use and provides opportunity for player choice.
-Some interesting puzzle elements not often found in the genre.
-Visual design is quite good in most areas.
-Creates a strong atmosphere of dread, terror, and horror in some areas.
-Good graphics quality, even for 2015, lots of well rendered gore.

Cons:
-Aside from a few unique enemies, most enemy designs follow the exact same formula.
-Level design is very repetitive, be prepared for many enemy-filled corridors.
-The game is quite dark, and although you have a flashlight on your gun, in some areas it's just an annoyance instead of being scary.
-The 3rd quarter of the game onwards gets super grindy with just tons and tons of enemies being thrown at you.
-The difficulty of the game does not flow well.  In the early parts, even the difficulty above normal is easy, in the later half, even normal can be frustratingly difficult.  Higher difficulty does not really make the game more challenging in a fun way and instead simply makes to so you die way more easily.
-This game is full of shrieks and loud static noises.  I had to turn the sound down because it was causing headaches.
-It's a gore-fest.

I am not reccommending this game because I think that in trying to be a action-horror hybrid, it falls short of each of it's parent genres in many ways.  Dead Space 2 is not a terrible game, but it is also pretty forgetable, and doesn't really excel in any way.

If you are looking for a gory space horror shooter to romp through I would recommend trying to pick it up on sale for a good price (<$10) and don't be averse to playing on a low difficulty.

(Note: the game comes with a bunch of free DLC weapons and armor which can trivialize the game.  If you want to have the original experience, do not purchase any weapons or armor from the store that cost 0 credits)

reviewText:
This game feels like it never ends
I normally don't write reviews but since I haven't seen any review that summarised my thoughts down here, I'll just write this stuff down. Keep in mind this is my personal opinion and if you are among the majority of people who enjoyed this game, then good for you, you can move on.

I am a Silent Hill enthusiast, I like horror games and so on but Dead Space 2 is not a scary game. Of course, most people tend to ♥♥♥♥ their pants whenever a light flicks but if you aren't easily scared chances are you will find this game boring, tedious and tiresome. I thought the first game wasn't too bad despite being a tad frustrating at times, but blimey I wasn't prepared for the amount of frustration this one can create.

First off, if you purchased this game and you expected to play it right away, you won't. EA will ask you to login with your EA account and they will try to convince you to do it by telling you you'll miss on some 'amazing' bonus content. But you can skip that part and avoid spending an hour trying remember what password your useless EA account had. Which is nice.

The game is filled with QTE which I'm not a fan of but I usually don't mind. But crickey, Dead Space 2's QTE are terrible. For some reasons you can't just casually press E but you have to mash it like a maniac and still, sometimes you end up dying anyway. It's like you are meant to die and enjoy your death scene - because dying is so much fun - and retry. My childhood was essentially me playing Metal Gear Solid so I know how to repeatedly press a single key, thanks to the torture part, and Dead Space 2's QTE are essentially MGS' torture part. Every five minutes.

The atmosphere of the game isn't too bad but it's completely ruined by the staggering amount of cheap jumpscares. When will game developers get that jumpscares aren't scary, they are just downright irritating. It wouldn't be so bad if they actually had just a few of them but no, the entire atmosphere is based on that. This clearly doesn't help you getting into the story, which by the way, is utterly predictable and cliché. Not once, was I even slightly surprised by any of the plot twists". Even Dead Space 1 managed to do that.

You are also supposed to do every tiny action which adds absolutely nothing to the experience. I can't remember how many times I asked myself "Am I actually supposed to do something or is this a cinematic?". And sometimes
date: the game also expects you to figure out stupid stuff you were never asked to do before like holding E instead of just pressing it. I did every single action just by pressing E
recommended: how am I supposed to figure out for this ONE action in the game I am supposed to hold E. I am not even kidding
hoursPlayed: there's actually some bloke in the devs team who thought for this ONE SINGLE ACTION it would add a lot to the game if you had to hold E instead of just pressing it. Unbelievable.\n\nIt might sound like details to you
voteText: but believe me this ruins the entire purpose of a game
helpfulPercent: which is to be enjoyable. The only thing I was looking forward to was the end
votesHelpful: so I could just let this game rot in my Steam library and never hit the play button ever again. But guess what
votesTotal: those were the longest 12 hours of gameplay in my entire life. This game feels like it never ends. Not to mention they thought it'd be a brilliant idea if that massively annoying regenerating necromorph would come and chase you while dozens of enemies keep spawning all around you.I won't even mention the final boss fight.\n\nOverall this game is a huge let down. They apparently managed to make Dead Space 3 even worse but I find it hard to believe. There are a few nice things to say about this game like the details they added into the environment and level design. Isaac feels less "stiff" and moving around feels way more natural. You can also kill babies and children which is something I wished games like Skyrim allowed you to do. But that's not enough to compete with the tremendous amount of problems this game has."

reviewText:
I was very much looking forward to playing this game. As I finally got the chance to play it, despite having it in my collection for a long while now, I played for around an hour.


PROS:
- The story seems very interesting.
- Good graphics for its time.
- Good cinematic scenes.


CONS:
- The camera kills this game. It was nauseating, and the fact that the camera is on the left shoulder of the character makes this game unplayable.
- Lack of actual ingame options to modify makes this game feel like it's missing a lot of depth.
- No actual save states - you can only save by going up to a terminal. Uhm... why are there checkpoints instead?
-  During the first scene where you run, I could not for the life of me understand that you needed to press on a button to fight back a specific enemy (while in the straightjacket). I needed to go on youtube to figure out what I was doing wrong. As I was using my PC keyboard, the onscreen instructions - for some reason - did not properly appear. The fact that they couldn't even get this simple vital thing in the game... you know, onscreen instructions, made me so annoyed as I kept dying ~10 times as I tried figuring out what I was doing wrong. Which happened to be nothing, as it was the game that was improperly designed.

reviewText:
Loved Dead Space 1 but this was just a big dissappointment.

The game launches with stupid action scene filled with quick time events. Ie. press the prompted buttons quickly or you're dead and get to start over. Combined with the fact that you've just set up all your keys around the keyboard (not quite knowing when or how you need use them) and are not yet totally familiar with them, this is a huge oversight from the game developers. Vigorous mashing of buttons and joysticks is something console games often resort to and I guess EA can't be expected to port their games properly, with consideration. Seriously people, DO NOT TRUST EA. They make games for profit and let down their audience, time after time.

The game was a gift to me and I'm sorry I ever added it on my wishlist. But honestly I hated playing it. Did I give the game a fair chance after playing the horribad intro scene for 40 minutes? No. Do I need to? No.

reviewText: In Dead Space™ 2, you join Isaac Clarke, the Systems Engineer from Dead Space, as he wakes up three years after the horrific events on the USG Ishimura. The Ishimura was a Planetcracker-class starship besieged by grotesque reanimations of its dead crew, known as “Necromorphs.” After unearthing a strange artifact known as the Marker, Isaac finds himself on the Sprawl, a giant space station in orbit around Saturn. Unable to remember how he got here and plagued with demented visions of his dead girlfriend Nicole, he must survive another nightmarish outbreak of Necromorphs as he fights his way towards an answer he hopes will end all the chaos.

reviewText:
Nothing like the first Dead Space experience.

This sequel is more action/shooter oriented, most of the survival horror elements present in the first game are lost. Dead space 2 isn't a challenge at all since early in the game once you reach the first store you unlock all weapons and suits (which for me ruined the game completely). You don't have to worry about oxygen anymore since you can just recharge it at oxygen stations (no more air cans in the inventory).

Jump scares are nonexistent. The atmosphere isn't as creepy as in the previous game.

Towards the end you get the feeling that EA just rushed through the game in order to give you a boring and upsetting ending.

reviewText: Dead Space 2 is basically just a generic action game with horror style enemies. reviewText:
It's more linear, it's more cinematic, it wastes more of your time, it destroys the story and the gameplay is poorer. It's generally just worse in every imaginable way.

Where before you could wander around a bit and explore each section you are now driven down a straight line with occasional loot chests hidden" behind a short dead end turn. The excellent pacing is gone in favor of shoving cutscenes down your throat every five minutes.
The gameplay is faster and more intense
date: in a system that isn't made for speed. Favoring memorization of enemies that will instakill/bumrush you over any kind of tactics or skill. Jumpscares will now gib you where the first game had the sense not to throw cheap deaths at you that you couldn't avoid.\nZero G doesn't work that way
recommended: good night.\n\nThe story contradicts the first game and adds nothing of value. All the way up until the end it is never made clear what is going on and you are left wondering who the villian is and why he is the villian. It fails to understand even simple concepts established in the first game
hoursPlayed: instead misrepresenting and retconning them as taken at face value.\n\nAdditionally

reviewText:
Dead Space 2: 5/10 Not RECOMMENDED
Dead Space 2 Impressions:
This is a nice game and yes it is better then the first... or is it?
It does have better graphics, it seems to have better controls... but something is off. It just does not feel as authentic as the first one... and it is (as the first one) highly repetetive... the story is... whatever... not really important... the circumstances are forced...
What is cool, are the new Z-gravity controlls, this is a nice addition, that should habe been in the first one.
This is a nice game... get it on sale... do not believe the hype... but I will not recommend this.

On a side note... Only EA knows how to punish you with free DLC... you get some mighty weapons and armor right from the start FOR FREE because the game comes with some lame DLC pack that includes those. It does not really breake the game, but surely goes against the intended survival aspect and it does make the store window overcrowded with useless items.

reviewText: I HATE THIS GAME.  I was very patient, and played through to chapter 15 (the last chapter)... despite the occasional spike in difficulty or ridiculous QTE sequence, like the blast from the solar array which is basically trial and error.  I developed a reasonable strategy over the preceeding 14 chapters as the difficulty remained generally even.  Then the last chapter arrived, and the difficulty shoots through the roof.  After spending about 2 hours playing the same sequence over and over, my opinion of the game dropped precipitously, mostly because the designers decided to  introduce an arbitrary mechanic to increase difficulty.  I rage quit and will probably not finish it,  I did enjoy the ambience, sound effects, general story, etc... but unfortunately the last chapter ruined it for me.  Not recommended.

reviewText:
The first Dead Space was fun and, overall, pretty good.  DS2 takes it to the next level - which is rare for a sequal.

Pros: Good graphics, excellent sound, good control, good story, compelling characters, good weapon / armor customization, decent variety of weapons and  enemies and quite scary in some areas.

Cons: Short (though average for a genre) and a bit linear.

Don't worry about the cons.  As you travel in this world you experience a vast array of unique situations from frantic fighting on a runaway train to being grabbed by the leg and dragged kicking and screaming before being tossed in to open space (thank goodness for space suits).  A WILD ride and one a recommend to anyone who loves scary shooters.
